TALK.START.PARA: —I join the debate today on the 1995 Loan Bill supporting my colleagues who have castigated the government in trying to manage the accounts—the accounts which, according to the budget papers, look a bit shonky. The bottom line is that, when it comes to money, this government, like all other Labor Party governments over the past decade, cannot cut it and just cannot seem to get it right.

PARA.TAB: Labor Party backbenchers come in supporting the executive of their party. They have been given a line. But I do not see many from marginal seats coming in and extolling the virtues of this issue. The reason is that they are embarrassed to put their name to the ongoing poor financial performance and management of this government.

The issue of debt and its management is a high priority issue in the electorate. This bill is supposed to be a mechanical bill which allows the government to draw upon funds to pay for its operation. In other words, the government requires bills like this to cover its holes in consolidated revenue. This bill allows the government to borrow more money. That is not unusual, but the government does it quite often.

During the 1980s we heard all sorts of people saying that greed was good. `Irresponsibility is okay so long as we enjoyed ourselves' was the cry of many, including, it appears, those on the other side. Greed could lead to many things, but in Australia it has led to a period of instability and huge losses of funds. We are considered by other countries to be not quite up to it when it comes to financial management, which is a shame. The reason for this assessment is that the lead that Labor Party governments provided during the 1980s was nothing short of corrupt. The Labor Party just cannot seem to manage money.

Let us take, for example, the Labor government of Western Australia, formerly led by the honourable member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), which lost huge funds during the WA Inc. period. It was a notorious period in Western Australia in which a former Premier and Deputy Premier were gaoled for theft of funds. These former Labor politicians, holding the highest office in parliament in Western Australia, played fast and loose with the state's till, and that state is now trying to work its way through the quagmire of huge public debt. The government was sacked by the people who wanted better management of their money.

Moving a little east, we see that the former Labor government of South Australia drove the State Bank into bankruptcy. The Bannon Labor government could not manage the funds and lost enormous amounts of taxpayers' funds in doing so. It was sacked by the people who wanted better management of their money.

Moving even further east, we see that the former Labor government sent the state of Victoria into virtual bankruptcy. The Cain-Kirner Labor government cost the Victorian taxpayer enormous amounts of public funds—a sad reminder that the Labor Party cannot be trusted to manage funds correctly. The government was sacked by the people who wanted better management of their money, and they did this by selecting Liberal governments in South Australia, Western Australia and Victoria.

Moving north into New South Wales we witnessed the Labor Party sending its own organisation broke by entering into ridiculous property deals which have cost its organisation and members enormous amounts of funds. It tried to play the property game and failed miserably. Of course, the senior members of this organisation walked the corridors of this place and the employed officers have been transferred to the New South Wales state government payroll. I am sure the taxpayers of New South Wales would be extremely happy about the failed officers of the Labor Party now drawing upon their taxes. The fact is that the Labor Party just cannot get the money management side of things right.

The Labor Party has the worst history of any modern parliamentary experience in Australia in managing money; yet day after day its members walk into the chamber and say that they are on track, the figures are good, the OECD is terrific and our comparisons are just wonderful. But the fact is that the Labor Party and its apparatchiks and fellow travellers cannot be trusted with taxpayer funds because they continually let us down.

I had cause to survey many areas of my electorate recently and the replies were very similar to the responses that came back from a survey my colleague the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) conducted in his electorate recently. If they are similar in Western Australia to what they are in New South Wales, then the assumption can be made that they are similar in all electorates. The message is quite clear: the Labor Party cannot manage money and the electorate is concerned about it. If this message is being heard in marginal seats of the ALP, we can be assured of one thing: on this issue alone the coalition will have a resounding success at the next election. The fear and lies so effectively used by the Labor—

—The fear and distortion so effectively used by the Labor Party in the 1993 election will not work again because the electorate has become cynical of the promises they get from the Labor Party. PARA.TAB: My research has shown that the biggest issue concerning the electorate is debt and the way it is being managed. The electorate rates the coalition as the only party which can provide the sound management practices which are required to bring back some sort of equity to all Australians. Mr Speaker, the fact that the government is looking for more borrowings should come as no surprise to you and the people of Australia. Racking up debt is the trademark of this particular government. Commonwealth public debt interest has increased a whopping 32 per cent—a figure increasing from $7.1 billion to $9.387 billion. Debt interest is on the way up. In other words, to those in the gallery, we spend $9 billion or thereabouts in interest every year.

This, of course, is in stark contrast to Liberal managed states which will see the public debt interest decline from $1.1 billion to $0.6 billion in 1996-97. What a difference a vote for the Liberal Party can make in some of these states. The comparison with the Commonwealth is stark and frankly not very favourable. The simple fact is that this Keating Labor government cannot manage finances and the result is the explosion of Commonwealth debt. The $9.4 billion we will pay in public debt interest equates to over $1 million per day we pay in interest. Each and every day of the year we pay over $1 million. This $9.4 billion does not go to hospitals or roads and cannot provide Australians those much needed tax cuts that have been promised before. It is all going to the financial markets. Not one benefit from the expenditure of $9 billion goes to the Australian people.

Members will recall that former Premier Kirner and former Premier Bannon both had problems with their banks. The Prime Minister seems to be following the Victorian Labor line of selling off the bank—in this case the Commonwealth Bank—in a desperate move to improve the figures. The government is selling off the cutlery, so to speak, to help it out of the financial difficulties we are now facing. But what sort of challenge are we facing? Most of the members opposite compare Australia to the G7 group, or the OECD or the other industrialised countries of the world. This is the modern cultural cringe they have: `My bank account is better than your bank account and my figures are better than yours.' But we are not truly an industrialised country, therefore comparisons are a bit out of proportion.

Sadly, if one views our performance with other countries, the shocking news is that we are honorary members of the Third World. When one thinks of the Third World, the images we see are the poor and suffering of Africa. We do not naturally see other images. Some countries we may not think of are in fact in the Third World. These include Brazil, Argentina, Mexico, Chile and perhaps even Malaysia.

I say that we are honorary members of the Third World when it comes to financial management, and to support this claim I would like to present the following figures. The percentage of debt to GDP in 1984 for Australia was 15.9 per cent. In Brazil it was 39.3 per cent; Mexico, 47.9 per cent; Argentina, 30.3 per cent; Chile, a whopping 73.3 per cent; and Malaysia, 35.9 per cent. These were the figures in 1984, just at the start of the Labor Party management of our country, and it showed we were performing pretty well.

In 1992, the percentage of debt to GDP for Brazil—these are the most recent figures available—instead of being 39.3 per cent in 1984, was 17.8 per cent; Mexico, instead of 47 per cent, was 22 per cent; Argentina, instead of 30.3 per cent, was 15.4 per cent; Chile, which was 73.3 per cent, was 15.7 per cent; and Malaysia, instead of 35.9 per cent, was minus 1.5 per cent of GDP in 1992. Australia in that same period has gone from 15.9 per cent of debt to GDP to 36.6 per cent. So in a period of 10 years we have gone past what the Third World countries were doing 10 years ago.

Many of those opposite talk about private debt and assure us that it is private debt which is the problem, but it is not. The South American countries I have just talked about are performing better than us. The banana republic that the Prime Minister spoke about 10 years ago is perhaps here right now. Unless we seriously address the growing problem, it will get worse and we will become a fully-fledged member of the Third World.

It is time we started to get serious about our financial woes and begin the long march back to some sort of responsibility. But this will not happen under this government—or any Labor government, for that matter—because it just does not have the will or the initiative. The current account deficit has been over $12 billion for nine of the last 10 months. Every month we pay out huge funds for interest on past foreign borrowings. In fact, every month our current account is over $1 billion before we even start trading—that is, $1 billion going out and paying past debts every month. It seems that all we are doing every month is adding to that debt.

The task before the government is to structurally reduce the debt, to lift national savings and to reduce its borrowing program. But the government seems incapable of providing the leadership and management to make this happen. To back up these allegations, we need look no further than the budget this year. It is really a great con.

We must reduce our expenditure; yet the government cut it by only $700 million. At the same time, the government has lifted up taxes by $2.3 billion. Then it swapped our public savings for private savings by selling our assets. Assets do not lift national savings. They do not do anything other than get some money in to pay off the operational costs this year.

In the budget there is no lift in national savings, which is what the crisis in financial management is all about. The government needed to cut its spending but was unable to do so. When it comes to management and making some of the hard decisions, the government is unable to.

Even last week there were examples of the government not being prepared to make some savings. Last week we had two Auditor-General's reports highlighting the continuing management incompetence of the government. One report showed that seven per cent of the Commonwealth work force—that is, some 10,000 officers—are non-operational. What are these 10,000 Commonwealth employees doing? No-one seems to know.

The other report showed that the tax department failed to collect $50 million it was due in tax. What is the government trying to do here? It is clear that it does not know what its work force is doing, whilst it is prepared not to collect the money that it is due. Could you imagine a small business, for instance, operating like that—not knowing what your employees are doing and not worrying about your receivables? The point is that a small business run like this would close down. It reminds me of a similar experience of a former government minister who ran a sandwich shop. He did not know what his staff were doing and he paid the ultimate price. I think the sandwich shop closed down, and he paid the ultimate price of having to resign as a minister.

He is not alone. The entire frontbench of the Labor Party has no business experience at all. In fact, the Prime Minister was sacked by David Jones some years ago. One of the reasons he was sacked was that he was arrogant and was never around the place when you wanted him. The attributes that saw him sacked then could also apply to him right now—he is a bit arrogant, and he is never around the place so that we can see him.

When the country needs the Prime Minister, where is he? He is strutting the world stage saying how wonderful it is that he can fix Japan's problems; and he puts up the Financial Times saying, `Look, France is following my lead here.' However, his manager at DJs did say that he was a good salesperson. All in Australia know that the Prime Minister is a great salesperson: he is like a slick snake oil salesperson, but we do not want a slick snake oil salesperson running our accounts.

Remember when Slick told us that he was not going to increase tax? We must remember that slick salespeople will say and do anything to get the sale, and that is what the Prime Minister did at the last election: he sold us a deal, and then he welched on it. He gave us a cheque, but the cheque was returned marked `Insufficient funds'.

Mr Speaker, there is no need to remind you of the 1993 Dawkins horror budget—it was a real shocker not only for the people of Australia but also for the Labor Party backbench. But I should remind you that the second stage of the indirect tax rises will fall into place on 1 July this year. These taxes, which it was promised to us at the last election would not go up, will go up on 1 July this year in the second stage of increases. So we will have tax increases ranging from three per cent to 10 per cent, increasing prices of consumables out in the marketplace and in the electorates. But Slick did not stop at the last election when he broke a few promises.

DEBATE.TITLE: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1995Cognate bill:FRINGE BENEFITS TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 9 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: p.m.)—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1995 proposes to amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to increase the rate of Medicare levy from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent for the 1995-96 and later income years. The bill will also increase the low income thresholds below which people will not be required to pay any levy and increase the upper thresholds for which special phasing-in rules apply.

PARA.TAB: Medicare levy receipts as a proportion of Medicare outlays have fallen from over 30 per cent in 1988-89 to an expected to 24 per cent in 1994-95. The adjustment to the rate will ensure that Medicare levy receipts make a greater contribution to the cost of government health programs. The benefit to revenue of the increase in the Medicare levy is estimated to be $230 million in 1995-96, $240 million in 1996-97, $260 million in 1997-98 and $280 million 1998-99. The estimated cost of raising the low income thresholds will be $10 million in each of the years 1995-96, 1996-97, 1997-98 and 1998-99.

The bill also makes a minor technical amendment to the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to increase the upper limit threshold for trustees of a trust estate for the 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years. There is no cost to revenue of these changes.

SPEECH.PARA: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX AMENDEMNT BILL 1995

The Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1995 will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986 to increase the rate of fringe benefits tax in line with the change from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent in the Medicare levy rate commencing from 1 July 1995. However, to avoid two different rates in the 1995-96 FBT year of tax the rate to apply to the year commencing 1 April 1995 is to be a composite rate of 48.475 per cent. From 1 April 1996 and all later FBT years the rate will be increased to 48.5 per cent. The benefit to the revenue of the increase in the rate is estimated to be $5 million in each of the FBT tax years 1995-96, 1996-97, 1997-98 and 1998-99. Full details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable members. I commend the bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1995. I note that, given their interdependence, this bill is being treated cognately with the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1995. My colleague the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) will be concentrating his remarks on fringe benefits concerns.

PARA.TAB: Let me say right now that the coalition will oppose this Medicare Levy Amendment Bill and will call for a division on it. We will do this because the budget increase in the Medicare levy from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent represents no less than another broken promise by Labor to the Australian community. It is another breach of faith that this government has dumped on the heads of the battlers of Australia—the working men and women who are not overly well off, who are struggling to make ends meet and who are striving to raise their families.

Let me share with the House a press release dated 19 June 1994 issued by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) with the interesting title `Claims of levy increase ridiculous says Lawrence'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: "Claims in this morning's newspaper that the Government is set to increase the Medicare levy are demonstrably untrue," Federal Health Minister, Carmen Lawrence, said today.
"There is no proposal to increase the levy and there won't be," Dr Lawrence said. "Both the Prime Minister and myself have repeatedly ruled out any increase."

We know what the word of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is worth. Let me repeat that key sentence for the benefit of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) and his colleagues on the other side: `There is no proposal to increase the levy and there won't be.'

PARA.TAB: From a government that has consistently promoted the use of plain English in official communications, this sounds pretty plain to me and to anyone else who has heard the minister on the subject. Let us make no mistake about this: the minister made her unequivocal statement on 18 June 1994, a month after Labor brought down its budget. So, within the space of a single budget cycle, her word has been turned on its head.

What this bill does, in the brief and matter-of-fact way outlined by the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) in his second reading speech, is to take yet another swipe at the battlers of Australia. People in the western suburbs of Melbourne or Sydney, in the south of my own electorate, in other capital cities and in the bush must be wondering where they are going to be hit next.

The raising of the Medicare levy is not just a broken Labor promise; it is a serious policy miscalculation. It takes and it gives back nothing in return. Let me explain. One of the myths that Labor has sold to the community with some success is that we pay our Medicare levy and our health needs are taken care of. In other words, Labor has sold to the Australian people the false impression that the Medicare levy receipts cover the total cost of publicly funded health care—that the two sides of the Medicare budget in fact balance. Nothing could be further from the truth.

If we look at the 1993-94 financial year, the last completed financial year, to get a picture of just how the Medicare levy revenue compared with expenditure on health care benefits, both public and private, we find the following: in 1993-94, according to the 1994-95 budget papers, the final estimate of the Medicare levy collected by the government is $3,030 million—let us say $3 billion. This is actually less than the contribution income received by private health funds in the same period, which was $4,150 million, or about $7.2 billion all up.

That is just the revenue side. On the outlay side, in the same period of 1993-94, the final estimate of Medicare benefits schedule payments was $5.4 billion. The final estimate for PBS outlays was $1,670 million and, just as important, the benefits paid out of private health funds in 1993-94 amounted to $3.5 billion.

Simple arithmetic tells me this combined benefits outlay for 1993-94 is about $10.5 billion and it is another easy calculation to subtract that amount received through the Medicare levy from this total payout. The quick answer is that $7,400 million of benefits, or 73 per cent of the total public and private benefit outlays, are not funded by the Medicare levy. This does not take into account the many millions of dollars paid by people who directly pay for their own medical or hospital care.

The government has always tried to sell the Medicare levy as an essential part of its strategy to contain the costs of delivering health care. I do not dispute there is a need for reasonable action by government and private insurers to contain costs of private insurance as far as it is consistent with effective quality care and fairness. But I think the simple exercise I have just done shows how much of a confidence trick this is on Labor's part. Nor, incidentally, do many people realise that the revenue from the Medicare levy does not actually get paid into any sort of earmarked account. Rather, it finds its way into consolidated revenue.

The levy has never been anything like hypothecated towards health care costs, which is why it is so dishonest for the Assistant Treasurer to come here and justify it on the basis of changing percentage of coverage of health care costs. Anyone who knows anything about the history of Medibank and Medicare would know the original proposals were for the levy to be set at 50 per cent of total expenditure. That was rejected by Treasury. So it is completely incorrect to come in here and attempt to use that argument.

The revenue and benefits figures I have quoted to the House raise a related issue, one which this government has failed to grapple with anything like effectiveness. No doubt, as this debate continues, members on the other side will try to point to the wonders that Labor has done for private insurance through its recent legislation. I will simply point to last week's release of the latest OECD report on Australia which has something to say about Labor and private health insurance.

The Prime Minister was very keen to crow about the OECD report. Indeed, my spies tell me that he was very unhappy that the Minister for Human Services and Health had knocked him off the front page of the newspapers with her statement to parliament. The Prime Minister was not crowing about this however: on page 125 of the report, after considering Labor's recent attempts at reform, the OECD says this:

SPEECH.PARA: In considering future reforms. . . it would be useful to have regard to whether the intended role of private insurance is a substitute for, or a top-up to, private arrangements.

In other words, the OECD says that Labor does not know whether it is coming or going in relation to private health insurance. I think I can help the OECD there. Quite clearly, Labor would be more than happy to see private health insurance disappear from the Australian health financing system.

PARA.TAB: The figures that I quoted earlier cannot be ignored; if they are, it is at the community's peril. Given that private insurance contributions outweigh Medicare levy collections and private insurance benefit payments come close to rivalling Medicare benefit schedule outlays, one can see that their role in health financing is a vital one in quality health care in this country.

And we have to face the undeniable reality that private insurance is under increasing strain as contributors drift away from membership at an ever-rising rate. In December 1993 the total proportion of the Australian community who had private insurance was 36.3 per cent. Over the 1994 calendar year this dropped 2.1 per cent.

In just the first quarter of 1995, the proportion decrease was to 35.6 per cent—a decrease of 0.7 per cent or, spread over a full year, almost three per cent. This is an ever-accelerating rate of dropout. At this rate, private fund insurance will be not much more than one in five by the end of the decade.

`So what?' those on the other side may ask, as they have on very many earlier occasions in this place. The answer is simple enough. If the money does not come from private insurance—or other self-provision for that matter—it will come from the public purse.

As the government knows, it has been reliably estimated that every one per cent fall in the level of fund membership results in an extra $100 million outlay in Medicare benefits. Or, to put it in a perspective that should have crossed the mind of the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and his advisers in framing this budget, the $230 million estimated extra revenue, to be taken in 1995-96 through the increase in this levy, will be more than offset by the cost of making provision for the increased demand on public resources caused by the exodus of private fund membership.

To be sure, this hike in the Medicare levy will put that much more pressure on middle income earners who have private health insurance but who wonder whether they can still afford the cost of the premiums.

The recent Healthwatch survey conducted for the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia provides some ominous messages for the government in this regard. One in seven privately insured people said that they are more likely to drop their private cover as a result of this levy increase. If one in seven people left at the one time, it would take private fund coverage to well below 30 per cent. The compensating public funding contribution would have to come from somewhere. This levy increase that we are having today is not just a little fiddle; it is not just another broken promise. It is positively harmful.

Overall, there is another question which the Minister for Human Services and Health put on the agenda by making a statement to the House about the findings of the Australian hospital care survey. That question relates to whether we are getting a quality health system in return for the billions of public and private financing dollars we inject into it. Elsewhere in this budget we see the government cutting back on the real level of grants to the states for the operation of public hospitals. Yet, if it says anything, the hospital care survey highlights just how fragile the balance between good judgment and error can be and just how easy it is to stray on the wrong side of that margin in the high stress intensity of hospital life.

Quality health care is not something that can be delivered on the cheap. We on this side of the House recognise this—some of us from our own experience as health care professionals. As much as we realise the need to control costs, we accept that this cannot compromise the basic quality of care offered in our health care system. This decision to raise the Medicare levy yet at the same time effectively constrict both the public and private resources to Australian hospitals and the level of support for private insurance is both misguided and short-sighted.

The Healthwatch survey to which I referred a short time ago also indicates that more than half of all Australians believe health services in Australia are getting worse, not better. Their confidence would have been further shaken by the sensational coverage of the hospital care survey, coverage which was fuelled by the way the story had been promoted privately to the media.

I am very concerned that this survey is being released so early at a time when we do not have the full information to understand what it means. I am concerned when I hear people talking on radio about incompetence and 14,000 deaths and at the same time I hear one of the authors of the survey cautioning that these are potentially preventable only.
We cannot support the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, as I said earlier. It gives effect to a wilfully broken Labor promise to the Australian people. I will repeat the minister's sentence a third time:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no proposal to increase the Medicare levy and there won't be.

That statement was made less than a year ago. We also oppose this levy increase because it gives nothing to a health care system that struggles valiantly to do the best it can, even with limited resources. Australians may expect more value for their health care dollar but they are getting less in both quality and quantity. In the final analysis there could be no choice for us other than to oppose this measure from a discredited government.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you will know that it is rising from a very high base. That indicates a stronger degree of satisfaction with that scheme throughout the community. It is certainly not the view of any member of this House that it is a pleasant task to increase any rate of taxation or levy. The Medicare levy is no exception. It has increased from one per cent, when the scheme was first introduced, to 1.5 per cent in the proposals before the House. But one cannot look just at the financial and statistical absolute level of that increase, the one per cent to 1.5 per cent—or, in the case of the most recent increase, from 1.4 to 1.5 per cent—over that 11 years. One has to look also at the nature of the outlays and the way the levy goes towards financing those outlays.

PARA.TAB: The Medicare levy reached a peak with some 30 per cent of health outlays being financed by it. In 1994-95, had the Medicare levy remained unchanged, it would have financed some 24 per cent of those outlays. If the parliament approves the increase now before us, the levy will finance some 27 per cent of those outlays. So while the levy has had to be increased, it has only reflected the general trend in health outlays in this country and in all other OECD countries. I will turn to that in a moment.

It is very relevant when one is considering the impact of the levy to also examine the way those health expenditures have changed and the way the Medicare levy goes towards financing those expenditures. It is not the case that the government has maintained, as a matter of policy principle, that the Medicare levy was intended or ought to fund 100 per cent—or some fixed, prescribed percentage—of medical and hospital outlays. That is not the objective of the levy.

As the opposition spokesman in this area pointed out, the levy is not hypothecated. I would be very opposed to any serious hypothecation of these kinds of taxation levies. The levy has a specific purpose and it is linked to the health system and to health outlays. It is a matter of government budgeting and management priority to determine how that should be reflected in the overall taxation mix. Health and outlays for health stand on their own—they are an arguable case—and the Medicare levy which is associated with that, but not directly linked in a statutory provision, needs to be argued separately according to the budget circumstances of the times and according to the economic circumstances of the population of the day.

It is very instructive to look back at the historical trend of health outlays. If we go back to the last significant period of coalition government—the 1950s, the 1960s and the early part of the 1970s—we find that, as a percentage of GDP in 1960, health outlays were some 4.9 per cent of GDP. That rose to the princely percentage of 5.7 per cent by 1970. From 1975 to 1985—I am combining a few of the figures—the average is about 7.5 per cent of GDP.

When we get to 1990-95 we find that we have reached the point of 8.5 per cent of GDP in approximate terms. An increasing percentage of outlays on health expenditure reflects a change in attitude in the developed world. If one tracks increases in per capita GDP throughout the world along with outlays on health care you can see a very strong correlation between the two. It is perfectly reasonable that as the population becomes more wealthy, through increasing per capita GDP, it is going to expect an increasing share of that GDP to be given towards the kind of personal benefits which health care provides. That is a very high priority for most people.

The OECD average is, at the moment, some 8.3 per cent of GDP. Therefore, we are slightly ahead of that. The EC average is 7.5 per cent, which is well below our average. The G7 nations come in at 9.4 per cent of GDP, reflecting the much higher level of expenditure that those countries have. However, I think you would find that many of those countries that have substantially higher expenditure, particularly the United States, fail to live up to the standards which we have set for our country and which the Medicare system has met. I refer to the quotation I read earlier which talked about a simple, equitable and universal system of medical and hospital coverage.

While there are many in the United States who are able to pay the higher medical bills and are able to be covered by insurance, that does not apply universally to the population by any means. I think it is very clear that our universal and equitable system is preferred. The recent debate in the United States Congress between the President and the republican group exemplifies the kinds of problems which we have managed to avoid in this country. It illustrates why our scheme, and those like it in countries such as Canada, is envied by other nations.

Nonetheless, we are in the position of having to increase the levy by 0.1 per cent partly because of the proportional changes in health expenditure but also to ensure that the revenue side of the budget is also addressed in this context. That is why I made the point earlier that this is not simply a decision about a Medicare levy but a decision made in the context of not only the health needs of the nation but also the budgetary and revenue situation of the government at any given time.

When looking at the impact of the Medicare system in this country, I think it is also very important to look at some of the ways in which it might be improved. We heard earlier in the quote about the OECD report that community satisfaction with Medicare is very high and continuing to rise. In relation to health expenditure per capita we compare well with other countries when we even up the issue of exchange rate variations. If we compare our health expenditure per capita with that of other countries in the OECD with whom we would customarily be compared and if we look at who is satisfied with their existing health care scheme we find that Australia comes out very well. We find that with Australians there is a high level of satisfaction for the level of expenditure which we incur.

Those countries which have higher levels of satisfaction all spend considerably more of their GDP on health cover, so they are buying that increased satisfaction at a very high price. It is a matter of continuing debate in Australia what percentage allocation of our gross domestic product should be put towards health care. We have to strike a balance in these issues. When we examine Australia's position on the graphs of satisfaction versus expenditure we find that Australia features well in that area and that the present arrangements strike quite a good balance for the population of Australia.

We need to examine a couple of matters in relation to what the opposition tells us about private health insurance and the impact the Medicare levy has on Australia's private health system. One issue is the absence of any definitive policy from the opposition in this area. Since the time of the Fraser government we have heard statements about the opposition maintaining the Medicare system or the precursor to that system. We have heard those statements and claims and many of us regarded them with some degree of scepticism at the time of the Fraser government.

We were right at that time. Recent trends have seen only a re-run of that kind of procedure with the prospective new member for North Sydney, Dr Brendan Nelson, who is well known to us here in his former capacity as AMA president. I suspect that he will become better known in his capacity as a Liberal candidate. One has to wonder when that transition occurred when looking at some of his speeches earlier this year.

The harsh reality is that the opposition has no clear and definitive policy with regard to how it will address the health care needs of this nation. Where there are policy initiatives taking place, we find substantial contradictions between those who allege to speak on behalf of the opposition about what they will be. Whether they maintain Medicare, bulk-billing and the existing scheme, which Australians may or may not rate highly, is something that we no doubt will have to wait somewhat longer to see, possibly days before the election. I caution members of the public to look very closely at the comments of members of the opposition to determine what that policy is, if they are considering it in an election context. I do not think we will get too much warning of it.

The issues of private health coverage in this country are often canvassed. The figures quoted are often quite misleading. They often reflect a decline in all those who have had at one stage any form of private health insurance. It covers those who at one time had private insurance to cover private treatment in a public hospital as well as those who have always maintained private treatment in a private hospital insurance context. They are quite different things.

Australians have quite properly identified that they are not getting terribly good value for money in paying private health insurance to arrange for private treatment in a public hospital. They will receive very good treatment in those public hospitals at the expense of the Medicare levy. That is what they are opting for. That is where we have seen the greatest fall in private health insurance numbers.

There has been a decline in the level of those at the other end of the system—the top end of the system—who are paying full coverage for total health insurance in private hospital areas. Their cover has dropped, but not by anything like the margins that we have seen in the overall decline of private health insurance. That is the area where the policy questions need to be addressed.

As the spokesman for the opposition pointed out, we have addressed those areas. This parliament has recently endorsed the government's private health insurance package, which will go some way towards ensuring that private health insurance is more open to competition in accordance with the Hilmer reforms, which this government is pursuing at a broad level. It will ensure that private insurance is free to offer people much more innovative packages than they have had in the past. In the past, private health insurance has been like the two-airline duopoly. We have seen a number of private health funds offering almost identical policies at almost identical prices with almost no competition between those funds either in the prices or the services which they offer or in terms of the breadth and depth of those schemes. We have certainly not seen any initiative or entrepreneurial activity in respect of the kinds of products that they offer.

The legislation which this parliament has recently approved will go a long way towards ensuring that the funds are able to offer better policies and packages to their clients. I believe that we will see the benefit of that over the next 12 to 18 months as they take effect. We will also see other initiatives in the area of casemix and incentive payments under the Medicare agreements. They will also contribute well towards the development of a more responsive health system.

I certainly endorse the remarks in the OECD report about the need for more appropriate incentives in some areas of our health expenditure. Those areas are well complicated by the relationship between the Commonwealth and the states and the need to enter into agreements with each of the states about the way in which they fund their public hospital systems. Those issues will have to be covered in Medicare agreement discussions between the Commonwealth and the states in the not too distant future.

I know that part of that discussion will be about the development of much better indicators of health care, health coverage, waiting lists and waiting times. Far better incentives will be built into the system to ensure that, like casemix, we have the right financial barriers to push people and hospitals in the right direction. It is essential that we have a very good handle on the information and data processing needs of that area to guarantee a very effective response by the health insurance system, be it public or private, to the changing needs of the client base and the changing efficiency and productivity relationships of the medical industry.

In conclusion, I commend this bill to the House. While it is never a pleasant duty to be involved in a debate which concerns a tax increase, even when it is of the order of 0.1 per cent as it is in this context, it is essential to look behind that fundamental point, that arithmetical point, and look at the underpinning structure which Medicare brings to this country. It has, indeed, lived up to the promise of 1984 to be a simple, equitable and universal system, one which all Australians have every right to be proud of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1995 and the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1995 are the latest bills to come before this House which add to and demonstrate Labor's litany of lies and deceit, in particular in the run-up to the last election. The Medicare bill increases the Medicare levy from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent. It also makes a minor upward adjustment to the low income thresholds for individuals, married couples and sole parents.

PARA.TAB: This increase in the Medicare levy is in spite of claims made by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) last 19 June, which the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) has raised, which are worth repeating. The minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no proposal to increase the levy and there won't be. Both the Prime Minister and myself have repeatedly ruled out any increase.

The minister went on to say that a rise in the levy was more likely under the coalition's policies. It was the old scare tactic: accuse your opponents of doing exactly what you intend to do yourself. The statements the minister made then are no more reliable than the statements made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on tax. Remember, our Prime Minister had the gall on the Lateline program of 19 November 1992 to say, `What I am promising is not to put up tax.' No-one could misinterpret those words. No-one could possibly misunderstand the meaning and intention of those words which were said prior to the 1993 election. Neither broken undertaking, either that of the Prime Minister or the minister, should be a surprise to anyone here.

PARA.TAB: The minister's record, both as a minister and as a Premier of Western Australia, is a total disgrace. Her performance in the federal parliament has been consistent with her efforts in Western Australia. In 1992, when still Premier, the minister decried the fact that Western Australia received too many tied grants. When the Prime Minister then suggested that the states could possibly have greater flexibility, so long as the Commonwealth could monitor the state programs, the minister—that is, the then Premier of Western Australia—said, `I've always found that a touch insulting, to be honest. The states are required to account for their expenditure to their parliaments and voters. I don't think if money is given to the states that it is, in a sense, any of the Commonwealth's business.'

The Minister for Human Services and Health has had another one of her famous attacks of amnesia because by June 1994 the same minister had somehow come to believe that it is very much the Commonwealth's business. When pushed by the states for greater freedom with health grants, the minister said, `History shows you can't trust the states with health funding. Just handing over large number sums of money with no strings attached and no penalties for failure to perform would be a betrayal of the Australian community. It's clear that it is not an option that could be endorsed by the Commonwealth.'

There is nothing like first-hand experience. Metaphorically speaking, you send a thief to catch a thief; you send the Minister for Human Services and Health into this Commonwealth parliament to catch up with all those terrible people in the state parliaments, one of whom was her—a very notable, if not successful, practitioner in the state scene. It is not surprising that the minister now supports an increase in the Medicare levy. However, I doubt there are so many gullible voters out there who will continue to believe her.

The second of the bills, the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1995, increases the fringe benefits tax rate from 48.4 per cent to 48.475 per cent for the year beginning 1 April 1995 and increases the levy to 48.5 per cent on 1 April 1996. The budget papers state that the increase in the Medicare levy `will ensure that Medicare levy receipts make a greater contribution to the cost of government health programs'. Remember that. It says `a greater contribution'.

The fact remains that in 1995-96 the Medicare levy is estimated to generate $3.6 billion in revenue, even though the outlays for the Department of Human Services and Health come to a massive $19.618 billion this same coming year, and expenditure on specific health related matters will be an almost equally massive $18.42 billion. Surely, if the government is serious about increasing the Medicare levy to ensure that a greater contribution is made by the levy to the cost of the provision of health services, there is nothing to rule out the government further increasing the Medicare levy. It is open-ended to put forward that justification.

Such logic means that Labor could increase the levy by 100 per cent to cover the cost of medical services and benefits or by double that again to cover the cost of hospital services. Using Labor's rationale, there is no upper limit on future increases to the Medicare levy until revenue generated by the levy equals the total cost of the provision of health services. That is a natural consequence of the excuse for this increase included in the budget papers. The Australian community should watch this space because, as sure as night follows day, Labor will continue to increase the Medicare levy.

Naturally, as the government increases the Medicare levy, it also increases the fringe benefits tax rate. The increase in the FBT rate reflects the government's desire to make sure that the top marginal tax rate and the fringe benefits tax are the same, otherwise there would be an incentive developed in favour of the fringe benefits tax away from income tax. The transitional rate of 48.475 per cent for the 1995-96 year has been explained in terms of avoiding two different rates applying in the same year.

The scope of FBT has grown way beyond what was originally intended; that is, closing a small tax loophole. This type of grab for even greater revenue is of great concern to taxation practitioners and to employers. Although not necessarily ever having subscribed to the policy behind the original FBT law, businesses have long bowed to the inevitable and come to accept that pure salary packaging benefits were irrevocably caught up in the FBT net. They accepted that.

The government has clearly stated that this particular tax grab will not be limited to benefits which are substitutions for what otherwise would have been taxable income in the hands of employees. Labor's aim is clearly to impose FBT more and more on so-called non-salary package benefits. Expenses of a business nature are to be caught up in the net, expenses that never were and never could be—except in the eyes of a revenue hungry Treasurer—construed as substitutes for salaries to individuals and to entire categories of employees. In other words, the FBT is a tax on business expenses that are not, and never were, benefits in the hands of employees.

Moreover, definitions for the so-called benefits to be brought into the FBT net are simply not available. There is simply an absence of knowledge. No-one knows, by dint of certain knowledge, of their obligations. So what will this mean? The chances are, once again, that discretion will be given to the Australian Taxation Office to decide the nature of business expenses to be caught up with the proposed extension of the fringe benefits tax net. That is hardly a recipe for either certainty or equity. The March edition of Taxation in Australia put it well in an article entitled `Milking it'. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The FBT is a champion little milch cow, that the government is accused of having force-fed, that it has become an overgrown and extremely clumsy beast. Originally designed to do no more than close a loophole exploited by a few high income earners, it has since intruded into an astonishing variety of tax areas. For many companies, it has become not only a cow to administer, but a bull in the China shop of company accounting processes and a nightmare of compliance.

The cost of compliance, along with the spread of the FBT, is the most insidious aspect of that tax. The fact remains that between 1987 and the 1996-97 fringe benefits tax year there will have been six different fringe benefits tax rates. These constant changes only add to the exorbitant costs in complying with this impost.

PARA.TAB: Businesses in this country face a cost of more than $1 billion each year in compliance costs. Of these costs, it is clear that the fringe benefits tax is one of the greatest elements. In 1989-90 the compliance cost for the fringe benefits tax was $128 million, which was 10.2 per cent of the total fringe benefits tax revenue of $1.2 billion.

For the same period, employers spent an annual average of 1,100 hours complying with FBT laws. This equates to a half time worker for the typical firm subjected to the fringe benefits tax. The compliance costs for employers' PAYE tax was $629 million, which was 1.4 per cent of the gross PAYE tax revenue. For payroll tax, the compliance cost was $206 million.

Australian businesses spend up to 11 times more than companies in the United Kingdom complying with direct tax obligations. Analysis undertaken by Challenge Bank shows that in 1990-91 on average 96 per cent of companies incurred higher compliance costs—at $10,129—than they remitted in income tax, which was an average of $7,079. It cost them more to remit the rotten tax than they actually collected.

Worst of all, compliance costs tend to be higher for the small business sector. Small firms with a turnover under half a million dollars spend on average three per cent of their turnover complying with taxation rules, compared with 0.2 per cent for companies with a turnover in excess of $50 million. Compliance costs generated by the current tax system markedly discriminate against small businesses. Small business has little to thank this government for. The Prime Minister, in an arrogant fashion, tells small businesses, `This is as good as it gets.' God help us if this is as good as it gets.

Even this most recent budget compounds the problems faced by the small business sector: it has slugged the small business sector with increased costs. For the information of honourable members, this includes the introduction of a sales tax on building materials, which will increase the cost of housing. There is a five per cent increase in the sales tax on non-luxury cars, as well as an increase in the company tax rate from 33 to 36 per cent. That latter tax applies to both large and small businesses if they are incorporated.

There is the new twice monthly PAYE remittance arrangement, as well as the increased FBT rate—which I have just been discussing. On top of that, there is the increased cost of lodging company documents and occupational licensing, fundraising and acquisition schemes. To top it all off, there is the adjustment of the interest rate which the Reserve Bank pays on non-callable deposits, which banks hold with the Reserve Bank of Australia.

All these proposals will add considerably to the cost structures that small businesses face and will make it much more difficult for a small business person to make an honest dollar. The fringe benefits tax has also made a big impact on the mining industry. This industry is, as everyone should be aware, an important employer in my own state of Western Australia. It is in fact the engine room for the west's economic strength and growth.

The mining industry is particularly vulnerable to the fringe benefits tax because, with mines being mostly in remote, uninviting locations, it is necessary to provide incentives to attract competent staff and to pay a competent work force. Many of these incentives could not be defined as a benefit but are more akin to compensation for having to live in a remote location. In contrast, manufacturers can locate their operations more readily in or near major urban areas and therefore have less difficulty in attracting staff.

It is obvious that the FBT legislation needs to be reviewed to take into account the incentives and compensatory payments made by mining companies. In a nutshell, the mining industry and small businesses need a simple FBT system with low compliance costs. This can only be achieved by a meaningful attempt to simplify and limit the scope of the fringe benefits tax.

Simplification of tax rules and regulations would not only make the lives of many ordinary Australians more productive but also increase national competitiveness and exports, and generate new sustainable jobs. To date, the government has spoken a great deal about simplifying the tax system but has done too little too late to further that stated objective.
Quite frankly, Labor's record is abysmal. As early as the 1985 tax summit, in a draft white paper the then Treasurer, Paul Keating, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A good tax system should be as simple as possible . . . to reduce the burden of record keeping . . . to increase the certainty of what is or is not taxable, and to increase the clarity of the tax system.
Labor has failed to meet even its own objectives as set by the then Treasurer, let alone those set for the government by the wider community.

PARA.TAB: On 24 February this year the Treasurer (Mr Willis) announced a package of measures resulting from the government's review of FBT compliance costs. Unfortunately, this announcement and the review it heralded have been too long in the pipeline. What is worse, this review offers little hope that the government is taking the issue of simplification seriously.

The serious shortcoming in how the government tries to simplify the FBT law, and other tax laws, is that it refuses to reconsider the policy foundations upon which the FBT and other taxes are built. In effect, the government only tinkers with the edges.

The FBT legislation foreshadowed in the budget has not yet been introduced into the House—though, because it applies from 1 April 1995, the coalition has been expecting it in this current winter sitting period. We are still waiting. While the expected bill will reduce some compliance costs associated—thankfully—with car parking, taxi travel, entertainment and living-away-from-home allowances, the government will increase the tax on employer provided cars to 10 per cent to offset expected losses in revenue. This further confirms Labor's true agenda with the FBT. It has only been expanded over the years because it is easy to squeeze out extra revenue from that source. The other issue related to this coming bill is that it already applies, although it is not yet the law of the land.

Labor has yet again legislated by press release. Taxpayers are to assume that the changes as outlined in a press release will be eventually legislated as stated in the press release. We have only to look at some past examples of legislation by press release by this government, and it would hardly be surprising if the government makes changes to the bill before, or after, it comes to this place.

Because the bill, when passed, will apply retrospectively from 1 April 1995, those taxpayers relying on the details of a press release could be in very deep trouble. After all, a press release has no standing in law when the legislation states something different. Legislation by press release is an administrative action which needs to be avoided at all costs—and particularly in these circumstances. Essentially, it offers too much scope for taxpayers to be denied natural justice and a fair go. The bill is opposed by the coalition.

It is aimed at promoting a national approach towards the improvement in quality of care. The Commonwealth has been saying for a very long time, `We have some problems in health areas, but they are administered by the states.' We have tried to use the Medicare agreements as a vehicle to provide both the money and the leadership to address those issues. The announcement of last week reinforced just how strongly those things are needed.

We should maintain that kind of leadership and maintain a shift in resources in terms of the health budget overall being increased compared with other budgets. That is happening, and the community wants that. It wants better health. I think the major issue in both the elections held in recent times, in ACT and New South Wales, was health. The community is signalling to us very clearly that it wants increases in health. How do we achieve that if there is not some increase in funding? I presume the opposition would argue to cut spending. One wonders how much of the opposition's $10 billion of savings in outlays would come from health. One day the opposition may well tell us where, if and how. The community accepts that more services cost more money. The community is also aware that the levy increase is by far the fairest way of financing that.

Other kinds of things have been developed in that period and I want to particularly mention the Australian health ministers benchmark working group. That works from the idea of trying to establish benchmarks between states, within states and across the country, and of using Commonwealth resources and leadership in doing that. One particular area is the rate of unplanned hospital readmissions within 28 days of the person leaving hospital. Another is the rate of unplanned returns to the operating room during the same admission. Those are the kinds of things we need to focus on desperately, given the concerns that came through last week.

I have often made the remark in terms of post-acute support in home and community care that we are much better off having people recuperating at home because homes are safer. One does not find much golden staph in people's houses. One of the issues for that ministerial benchmark working group has been the hospital acquired infection rate. That really is an extremely important issue. We know it happens, but we have to do something more about it than simply talk.

The whole point of this is that these things are additional programs. They actually cost more money. We come back then to the process. Before the Medicare agreements were introduced in 1984, the Commonwealth simply gave the states some money and we can see the result of that: there was no leadership, there was no uniformity and there was no cross-referencing. In the 10 years since then, we have seen a much greater coming together of our systems across the country. Ministers, state and federal, are meeting and developing uniform approaches so that we start to develop a truly national health system.

The fact is our health system in world terms is good, but it could be better. We have to keep working at it all the time, because the day we stop trying to make it better will be the day that it will fall in a hole. The figures of last week show that. The opposition has argued at various times over the years, certainly way back in 1983, that the Medicare levy was really states business; it was none of our business. The fact is the community does not agree with that.

The community has endorsed this government and Medicare election after election after election. It has endorsed increases in the Medicare levy previously. From my own comments and feedback from my community, it certainly accepts this as being a much fairer way. The community wants health to be improved. It wants the Commonwealth to lead in that way. The community wants Medicare to be endorsed and supported, and it wants people to contribute from their capacity to pay, not from the idea of user pays.

If you get the disease, you pay for it yourself—that is the philosophy that we have heard so much about throughout our country's history. That philosophy has changed and the community has endorsed that change. This increase in the Medicare levy is a fair increase. It does not fully redress the shift in balance of the levy contributions to the total health budget. It is still three per cent behind what it was six years ago, but the fact is that this increase is a fair way of approaching it. It is clear that it is not just I who endorses the legislation but the Australian community. I commend it to the House.

PARA.TAB: Essentially, the Medicare levy is an extension of income tax, though with alternative thresholds. It is a tax on one's income. The OECD report to which I referred also included two other interesting and pertinent statistical points. Firstly, the major reasons for dissatisfaction with Medicare appear to be hospital waiting lists and poor hospital service, with 23 per cent of those surveyed mentioning those points. The OECD report stated that there were 7.2 people per 1,000 waiting for elective surgery in 1984. Of the elective surgery patients, all but one category—cardiothoracic surgery—had a percentage of patients waiting over 12 months to be admitted. That is an appalling statistic.

An MBF survey last year revealed that 20.4 per cent of respondents or their immediate family had to wait to get into a public hospital; 62.2 per cent said that they knew of others who have had to wait to get into a public hospital; and 84 per cent were concerned about waiting lists for public hospitals. One reason for the large waiting lists is a result of increased reliance on Medicare. This came about, I believe, at the introduction of Medicare. People were led to believe they were covered by Medicare and as soon as something went wrong Medicare would cover them.

Medicare was introduced to provide universal health insurance for all Australians. There is nothing wrong with that objective. People with private health insurance who could afford to maintain their membership of private health insurance dropped out, relying instead on Medicare. Many people who could afford to take out private health insurance—the Prime Minister and the Minister for Human Services and Health are two examples—do not have it. The procedure cost $650. His private health insurance gave him $458. He could have covered the whole procedure with what he had put into private insurance over the last few years and still be in front. He has now withdrawn from private health insurance. A constituent wrote to me in February of last year:

SPEECH.PARA: My wife and I contribute handsomely to Medicare via the annual levy. In addition, we are members of the Hospital Benefit Fund at the highest level, including Ancillary Cover. During November 1993, my wife Michelle underwent a serious operation at St John of God Hospital, Subiaco. The doctor's fee for this service amounted to $1,988. Medicare refunded $722.20 and HBF $240.70, a total refund of $962.90. We were thus confronted with a balance to pay of $1,025.10 . . . It dreams up its own rebate for the service, but still leaves a massive gap because it takes no notice of the normal charges of doctors—charges, I might add, which in the norm recognise their work and skill.

PARA.TAB: But the main fact is that encouragement needs to be given for people to take out private health insurance and to keep it. If more people continue to drop out, it will simply add to the burden on Medicare. There are wealthy people who use Medicare but, if they need a procedure where they must endure a wait, they can afford to pay for it. One lady I know of, and I should point out that all of you know this lady—and two doctors rang my office and confirmed this—needed a cholecystectomy. Private health insurance is important for the government to restrain spending. The OECD report on Australia talks of the ambiguous role of private insurance in the Australian health care system. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . insurance is supposed to be an optional add-on to the universal Medicare scheme, paying for choice of surgeon and better quality hospital accommodation. But if this were really the case, private inpatients would pay only the extra costs of more comfortable accommodation and choice of surgeon. Instead, they pay for total accommodation costs plus all other costs apart from the Medicare benefit for medical services. These contributions are estimated to save Medicare some $2 billion a year.

The report also, when dealing with the high level of activity in private hospitals for procedures for which public waiting lists are long, suggests that access to treatment is obviously not based on clinical need—rather, on the ability to pay—and, therefore, it violates one of the foundation principles of Medicare and undermines the equity of the health system. While the principles behind Medicare are excellent and worth while, there are still some fundamental problems. Private health insurance should be complementary to Medicare and not a substitute for it. Encouragement needs to be provided for people to go back to private health insurance.

PARA.TAB: Graham Richardson, when he was the health minister, said that he would be worried if the number of people with private health insurance dropped below 40 per cent. It is now well below that, and the minister and the Prime Minister should set an example by taking out private health insurance. A recent poll by MBF found that 74 per cent of Australians believed that the Prime Minister and the minister for health should take out private health insurance, but they are yet to heed that message. Seventy per cent of those surveyed who hold private health insurance are likely to drop out as a result of the levy increase. The glossy image of Medicare painted by those opposite turns out to be a mediocre system when you apply the turps and see the real image beyond the government's claims.

It seems that greater reform is needed for Medicare so that it does allow for private health insurance to succeed, so that individuals and families on higher incomes are encouraged to take out private health insurance and so that lower income earners, those for whom Medicare was essentially designed, are not forced to wait for admission to hospital longer than is desirable in the opinion of the clinician. I oppose this bill for a number of reasons: it is a dishonest tax rise; it will not improve the operation of Medicare, which is needed; it hits the battlers of Australia, who are suffering enough as it is; and it will further erode the membership of private health insurance, which is a crucial component of our health system.
