TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty-four per cent.

—You probably need a levy as high as 24 per cent to go anywhere near raising enough money to directly pay for health care costs—not that there is any honest attempt, as the shadow minister said earlier, to hypothecate the Medicare levy towards the cost of health care. In that sense there are arguments for incorporating it in the tax scales and for recognising it for what it is: part of the tax system.

PARA.TAB: The increase from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent increases the top marginal tax rate to 48.5 per cent—one of the highest in the world, and we wonder why people in Australia cannot save. People cannot save simply because we have a government in this country that constantly tells us that it is better at spending our money than we are.

This big taxing government has done it again in this budget at every turn. Through increasing the Medicare levy from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent, it will raise $250 million per annum on average over the next few years. This comes at a time when many people are struggling to retain their private health care cover. In the last five years, 1.2 million people have dropped out of private health care. Now only 35.6 per cent of Australians across the board have retained private health care.

When these 1.2 million people dropped out of private health care, where did they go? Quite obviously they went straight into the public system and onto the end of the queues and the waiting lists. The member for Cowan referred to one particular instance, but each of us can refer to many examples in our own electorates of people who are on waiting lists for surgery of all sorts for varying conditions.

I wonder why people are not given a true opportunity to choose between being in private health insurance and not being in private health insurance. Almost all of the 1.2 million people who have dropped out over the last five years would probably tell us that they were forced to drop out simply because they could no longer afford to maintain their private health insurance.

One question that keeps coming to mind is why the Prime Minister does not have private health insurance. Surely somebody who earns as much as he does should not be loading up the public system. He of all people should be setting the example by having private health insurance. I presume that if he needed surgery of some sort he would simply take the view that he could afford to pay to go into a private hospital. The fact is that he should not be loading down the public system. Many people wonder why the Prime Minister does not have private health insurance himself.

Speaking on behalf of a number of my own constituents, I know that many older people and many pensioners struggle to retain their private health insurance. The bulk of people in the private health system are older people. Almost by definition they see the very clear need for private health insurance. There is a problem in the private health system in that it is harder to encourage younger people to get into it. Clearly the users of the system are also the ones who are in it, and they are mostly older people.

People dropping out of the private health system will have the effect of making it more expensive. Once the costs are spread across a smaller number of subscribers, private health insurance will become more expensive despite the government's latest ham-fisted attempts to try to fix the problem.

Many aged people, pensioners and self-funded retirees will struggle to maintain their private health insurance. Unfortunately, many of them will be forced—not as a matter of choice—to drop out of private health insurance simply because they can no longer afford to be in it. Self-funded retirees—I have many constituents who are in that category—will have to pay this increased Medicare levy.

We need to concentrate for a moment on the plight of self-funded retirees in this country. I take every opportunity to do so because I have a large number of them in my electorate. Let me make the point: these are the people who have done exactly what we want every Australian to do. Let us not cast aspersions on those who have not done it, but let us be aware of the fact that these people have been fortunate enough in many cases—and frugal enough in others—to have provided entirely for their own retirement. But what reward do they get? They get absolutely nothing. In fact, they get the reverse. They have been consistently treated badly by this government for having done the right thing and provided for their own retirement.

They will pay the increased Medicare levy. They will be slugged by that. They will struggle to continue to pay their private health insurance. They get the double whammy of this budget: they get an increased Medicare levy but they do not get their promised tax cuts. Obviously, by definition, they have already retired, so they do not benefit in any way from the government's you-beaut plans to convert the tax cuts into some sort of superannuation contribution down the track. So self-funded retirees miss out there. Things become increasingly difficult for them.

Families, despite some minor changes to the thresholds of this legislation, will pay the increased levy. Many families who are in private health insurance—these are often families with young children or young married couples intending to have children—want to be able to make the choice of going into a private hospital. They will struggle to maintain private health insurance, and they will pay the increased Medicare levy as well.

There are lots of very clear reasons why we should oppose this tax increase. I make that point very purposefully. We are talking here about a tax increase. We were promised that there would not be any tax increases, and we will not allow the government to get off scot-free. One member of the government is in this House at the moment, the member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay). As my colleague observed, very few government members will come in here to face us in these debates on tax matters, probably because they are hanging their heads in shame. But we will drag them in here to vote on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, and they will vote in favour of it. We will sit on this side during the division—which I assume will occur early this afternoon—and vote against these tax increases. Hopefully, the people will observe government members sitting on that side voting in favour of tax increases.

We will also oppose the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill for pretty much the same reasons. It is a consequential amendment bill because it relies on the top marginal tax rate. It is also simply another broken promise. For the same reasons I have already outlined, we will vote against that bill. That is our objection.

What is a promise worth? Obviously not very much. I suppose that most Australians who have listened to the government making these promises or who have read about them will shrug their shoulders and think, `Well, that is a political statement of some sort.' But where is the credibility? There is none. The government made promises. They were not ambiguous promises, ambivalent promises or even equivocal promises; they were promises that something would not happen, yet it did. That is why we are objecting to this.

What is the difference between a broken promise and a lie? I suggest to you that there is absolutely nothing. That is why we had the debate in here yesterday after the Prime Minister made a statement accusing the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) of having said something which he had not said. Naturally, the Leader of the Opposition took exception to that. I think we had to have that debate. I suppose this was the debate that we `had to have', if I can borrow that terminology. We clearly exposed to the people of Australia—as if it needed any further exposure—this Prime Minister's incredible capacity to tell other than the truth and to attempt to get away with it. But he did not get away with it yesterday. That little exercise exposed him for what he is and he was caught out.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was stunned.
—Yes, as my colleague says, he was stunned by that yesterday. We will continue with that type of exposure in the run-up to the next election.

PARA.TAB: I believe that this election will be about credibility. This debate today is about credibility. We are debating today what seem to be, in a sense, in terms of revenue measures, fairly small issues—but they are huge in terms of the question of credibility. The debate today really focuses on the credibility of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Human Services and Health who could make absolutely clear statements about tax increases and Medicare levy increases, yet we are asked today to vote in favour of these increases. We will not do that and, in this particular matter, we will show all government members up for what they are.

The fringe benefits tax, which we are dealing with here, has been a resounding success for the government since it was introduced in 1986. I note from the budget papers that this year it will raise almost $3 billion. I say that it has been `a success', but I am not sure whether that is the right way to describe a tax. It certainly has been successful in collecting a whole lot of money. There have been many inconsistencies with the way the government has gone about applying that tax, and the government has reversed some of those in recent legislation. However, there remain three areas of concern: the application of the assessment process; the application of fringe benefits tax to business expenses, which are not exactly benefits to employees—I noticed that my colleague the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) in his contribution to this debate dealt in some detail with that—and the impact on the fringe benefits tax on the pattern of spending, particularly as it affects restaurants and the tourism and accommodation industry.

As a result of this legislation, fringe benefits tax now is set and will be set retrospectively, incidentally, by a couple of months to 48.475 per cent. It will go the full way to 48.5 per cent from 1 April 1996. One of the problems is that this is higher than are some employees' tax rates—and that, of course, would apply mostly to part-time employees. So cashing out from any employers is not an option—and that, of course, means that this is just one way in which the FBT mechanism is flawed.

There is no doubt in my mind that the imposition of this tax has been extended way beyond its original intentions. It might have been one of those things which was a good idea at the time, although I never supported the way it was imposed on employers rather than employees—but I think the horse has bolted well and truly on that. The fact is that it has gone way beyond its intentions. We now see situations, particularly where award requirements or deals are negotiated—enterprise agreements between employers and employees—that actually provide for certain conditions, where they then are clearly not fringe benefits. Yet there are still a number of instances where employers are being required to pay fringe benefits tax on benefits which are not in that sense benefits at all but are requirements of the employee's job.

I will finish on that point. I am very pleased and proud to stand here today and say that we will vote against these tax increases. I hope it will be appreciated by the people of Australia that we want to restore integrity to the political process. I hope we will; I believe we will. I believe that we will not promise things we do not intend to deliver. When we win the next election, we will not have our leaders running around saying that things are other than they are. I want to see integrity restored to the process and, in my view, our vote today will be evidence of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieberman The Hon L.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation increasing the Medicare levy, the subject of part of this debate, is legislation to increase taxes—taxes the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) promised he would not bring in. Under this legislation, the Medicare levy is to be increased from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The fringe benefits tax legislation—I will refer to this very briefly because I mainly want to talk about the health policy, the budgetary policies and the broken promises attached to that—will only reinforce in the minds of many people in Australia, particularly in small business, that this government is intent on raising more and more revenue from the very people who will provide the greatest hope for recovery in Australia and will provide the greatest job opportunities for our unemployed, particularly our young. Of course, I refer to small business.

Wherever you go in Australia—Mr Deputy Speaker Snow, I know that you are attentive to the needs of your constituents—you hear small business people lamenting the high cost of compliance imposed on them by government taxes. In fairness, they are not just federal taxes; they are also state taxes—but certainly they are predominantly federal taxes. These people mention their dismay at the ever increasing costs, particularly in relation to fringe benefits. I take the opportunity to again record my dismay on behalf of many Australians at what this government is doing.

I also take the opportunity to place on the record again, in the few minutes I have, that on 26 February 1992 the Prime Minister announced in his One Nation statement that he would deliver tax cuts in two rounds, costing $3.5 billion each. He said that new tax scales would be introduced in two stages—on 1 July 1994 and 1 January 1996. On 9 February 1993, in another statement—the Prime Minister has a propensity for launching statements with rather generous descriptions of them; this one he called Investing in the nation—at the National Press Club, when questioned about the promised One Nation tax cuts, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: They are not a promise, they are law—L,A,W—law. And the difference between a legislated tax cut in some Opposition speaker's manifesto is all the world of difference, and they were signed into law at the end of the last parliamentary sittings.

After the election, back at the National Press Club on 22 July 1993, the Prime Minister announced that `the tax cuts now legislated are to be paid in two parts—one in July 1994 and the second in January 1996'. In the August 1993 budget, the then Treasurer announced that the timing of the income tax cuts rate scale changes announced in One Nation would be altered but that the tax cuts would be delivered. What do we find now in June 1995, a little over two years since the Prime Minister made these commitments on 9 February 1993, when he reminded Australians that legislation had been passed through this parliament to ensure that his promises would be delivered?

PARA.TAB: We find that in its first two budgets this government has, in fact, broken its major promises regarding no new taxes and has increased taxes substantially. I will briefly review them. In the 1993 budget the Prime Minister introduced new taxes to reap about $3 billion a year in unused long service leave taxes and annual leave lump sum payment taxes, it increased tax on credit unions, it increased fringe benefits taxes and it brought in an increased general rate of wholesale sales tax—up two percentage points. I remind honourable members that one per cent came in last year and the other one per cent comes in on 1 July this year. Those things are as a result of last year's budget. We have not even seen the effect of the increases in the budget being debated during this session.

The Prime Minister increased the general rate of wholesale sales tax, as I said, by two percentage points. He put an extra sales tax on wine and cider. He increased petrol excise by 7c a litre for leaded petrol and 5c a litre for unleaded petrol. The country people of Australia, some of whom I represent in my electorate of north-east Victoria, would love to tell the Prime Minister personally how that has impacted on their family budgets, their businesses and their costs because of the extra fuel that country people have to use in their everyday living, let alone in their employment. He increased tobacco excise in the 1993 budget and introduced a departure tax. Those were the taxes that he said he would not introduce but were in fact introduced.

Now in this budget, in this bill, we see an increase in the Medicare levy from 1.4 to 1.5 per cent, which he promised he would not increase. The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) gave a commitment on behalf of the government that Medicare would not be increased, even after the election, even after the months when it was obvious that the government knew it was in a financial dilemma and that it was pulling the levers the wrong way in mismanaging the economy and had to stem the haemorrhage but was not courageous enough to stem the haemorrhage and manage the services of government efficiently.

In this budget, apart from the Medicare levy, we see an increase in company tax from 33 to 36 per cent, which will raise another $320 million. I remind honourable members again that much of that extra revenue will come from small business, which has not, in many cases, recovered from the recession, which has depleted its reserves—most small businesses are operating on an overdraft and higher interest rates which have increased three times in the last 12 months. This government is now asking those people who create new employment in Australia to bear a greater tax burden, after he promised them he would reduce their corporate tax rate to 30 per cent. He now wants to increase the rate to 36 per cent.

The extension of sales tax in this budget to certain building materials raises another $215 million and will impose extra costs on many people, particularly young home buyers, up to about $1,000 or so. There is some debate about the amount. I think the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) would know that I am about right when I say that figure. The sales tax on passenger motor vehicles will raise $330 million and a greater sum over the four years of something in excess of $1,400 million.

With that scenario we then look quickly at the health position and we see that what the government is doing is adding to the costs of running families—in this case an increase in the compulsory Medicare levy. The direct effect of that will be an acceleration in the number of people who will exit from private health insurance. We are already heading towards 700,000 to 800,000 Australians who have exited in the last 18 months or so. In the 12 years of Labor government, we have probably seen in excess of three million Australians exit from private health insurance. The consequence of that is that it has added to the cost of running the Medicare system, added to the cost of the provision of public health care in Australia.

So it is sheer madness for a government, without putting in place some means of ensuring that families will remain in private health insurance, to increase taxes through the Medicare levy at this stage. It will only accelerate the number of people who will depart from private health insurance. Consequently, it follows as a matter of logic that more people will be seeking public hospital care in the next year or so.

The cycle will then get worse as more and more people join the queues in public hospitals, as more and more people seek essential services, as more and more people want to know why they cannot get it straight away, as more and more problems occur, such as the one the minister for health referred to in her ministerial statement last week about mistakes in hospitals—perhaps even worse—where, unfortunately, some 14,000 Australians appear to have suffered great misfortune due to problems in hospitals. Many, not all, of those problems were attributable to hospitals being unable to cope with the increasing demand on them due to the number of people exiting private health insurance and looking for what the previous Prime Minister Mr Hawke promised on behalf of the Labor government—access to public health care whenever you want it because you are part of the Medicare system.

It is clear that this legislation is only going to make the position worse. The health minister, I am sure, if she were given the opportunity to be frank, would exclaim that this legislation should be defeated; would agree with the opposition that it is only going to make her task harder to provide these services.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Do you concede that Australia's high foreign debt, which the Labor Party took from $23 billion in 1983 to $167 billion today, is one of the main reasons why Australians pay the highest commercial interest rates amongst major industrialised countries? Is it the case that an Australian with a $100,000 mortgage is paying $5,000 in interest more than an American with the same mortgage on the US adjustable home loan rate? Is this as good as it ever gets for home buyers in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that Australia has increased its foreign debt over the last decade and a half is something which is attributable to the deterioration in our savings performance going back to the middle of the 1970s. As has been acknowledged by a member of the Liberal Party executive, the fastest rate of growth of foreign debt in Australia was during the period when the now Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer. That growth in debt is something that we would rather not have happening in this country, but it has to do with the fact that we allowed that weakness to develop in terms of savings during the period of the late 1970s and early 1980s.

PARA.TAB: I refer to Treasury statement No. 2, page 35 of Budget Paper No. 1. Talking about the current account deficit, it says:

ANSWER.PARA: Whereas in the 1960s and 1970s the deficit averaged 2 1/4 per cent of GDP, in the 1980s and 1990s it has averaged 4 1/2 per cent, with much of the deterioration occurring in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was in government then?
—The late 1970s and early 1980s was when the now Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer. That is the Treasury's view of when the deterioration occurred.

PARA.TAB: As the Prime Minister said yesterday, essentially since we have been in office, after the first two or three years, the level of debt as a proportion of GDP has largely been stabilised. In fact, in recent years—in the last year or two—it has come down from a bit over 40 per cent to 37 per cent. Yesterday's figures showed only a slight increase. That was solely due to valuation effects—not to any underlying increase in debt in Australian dollars, but just valuation effects due to the devaluation of the Australian dollar.

The foreign debt situation has improved in recent years—in the last couple of years. It has been this government's job to try to make up for a situation of substantial deterioration which occurred during the period of the previous government.

In terms of the future, obviously it is important that we get that current account deficit down. In the budget I have announced major steps towards achieving that. Those steps will involve our being able to tackle our not too flash savings performance, by way of improving our budget dissaving to get the budget deficit into surplus and to bigger surpluses in the out years so that we do not have public sector dissaving and that major drag on the national saving performance; and a major boost to private sector savings through the superannuation initiatives, which will certainly have a dramatic impact on household savings in the course of the next decade or two.

Those are fundamental, sound structural changes to savings in this country which will have enormous impact in terms of our current account performance in the future. As the Treasury has pointed out in statement No. 2, the major factor behind the current account deficit moving to 4 1/2 per cent of GDP average in the eighties and nineties was the public sector decline, and it is the restoration of that public sector savings performance which this budget brings into absolute focus.

In terms of the wholesale market, interest rates have been moving down notably, and anyone who looked at the papers today would have seen that the 90-day bank bill rate is less than the official overnight rate—less than 7 1/2 per cent—and that the long-term bond rate has come down to about 8.6 per cent from over 10 per cent not so long ago. Clearly the markets are looking at Australia and saying that inflation is substantially under control—and of course it was a lack of control over inflation, going back over the last couple of decades until the latter part of the 1980s, which gave Australia a burden to wear in terms of higher interest rates.

We now have a strongly growing economy with low inflation, and that is something that could not have been dreamed about a dozen years ago when we came into office. It is something which is absolutely in place now. We have had low inflation for the last several years, and a continuance of low inflation is certainly something that the markets now expect. As we earn our spurs, we will see our interest rate performance get better and better.

That is an important privilege which members of parliament should, rightly, enjoy. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. On 30 May in parliament you referred to the problems in the US `in terms of falling real wages and the vast number of working poor'. The unemployment rate in the US is much lower than in Australia. Real average weekly earnings in Australia are now lower than they were in 1983. According to the Union Bank of Switzerland's latest survey of prices and earnings around the globe, an unskilled builder's labourer in Los Angeles earns wages 90 per cent higher than a comparable labourer in Australia. How can you say to those labourers that this is as good as it ever gets?

—What an absolutely ridiculous question. On 30 May I was referring to statements made by the US Secretary of Labor at the OECD in which he said that he was greatly concerned about the fact that the United States labour market had produced relatively low unemployment, which was a good thing, but at a price which he saw as being very high. He was greatly concerned about that price—that price being that there was tremendous disparity in wages within the labour market and that disparity had meant that there were lots of working poor.
—And they have better wages than we have in Australia.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has asked his question.

—That is the kind of outcome which is there in the United States. I am doing this from recollection. The figures produced in the OECD job study show that, if you take the wage at the top of the lowest decile of wage and salary earners and compare it with the wage at the bottom of the top decile, the disparity for Australia was about 2.23 times and for the United States was about 5.4 times. So there is a markedly greater disparity in wage outcomes. This means that within the United States there are many people doing very well and many others doing very poorly, even though they are in full-time employment or are largely employed. Pointing to one building worker—
—No, it is the rate! It is the rate!
—building workers, of course, being one of the highest paid groups of manual workers in any society—obviously does not say anything. They are comparatively well paid in Australia.
—But 90 per cent lower than in the United States!

—Building workers are well paid in Australia in comparison with other workers of a similar skill level. We all know that to be the case. It is true in the United States and everywhere else that building workers are generally relatively well paid for their skill level. This comparison of the real wages between two countries, of course, is fraught with all sorts of dangers, and one cannot simply make that comparison validly.
—You started it.
—No, I didn't.
—Yes, you did. You did!
—Order!

—This is an idiotic circumstance. What I said on 30 May, referring to the labour market in the United States, was, `We don't want that labour market here.' You do; that is what you want. You want a totally deregulated labour market. You want a labour market which would have the outcome that the Secretary for Labor in the United States went to an international forum and said was a bad outcome and one that he was greatly concerned about. That is the kind of outcome that you would like.

PARA.TAB: The opposition is trying to imply here that there are some higher wages in the United States than there are in Australia. Certainly it is true that GDP per person employed in the United States is higher and that the wages probably on a translation across to Australia are higher. That is because it is the richest country in the world in terms of income per head. Of course it has got higher real wages taken as an average.

The important point is that, if you are concerned about battlers—as you say you are—then the United States labour market is the one which does nothing for battlers. It is the market which produces these enormous disparities and which produces an outcome of large numbers of working poor in circumstances where real wages, which is part of Mr Reich's comment, had not been increasing for years. In the United States the median wage had not been increasing at all. In fact, the wages of many people were going backwards. That is the kind of circumstance which the United States government is rightly concerned about.

We do not want to see here the kind of deregulation of the labour market which the opposition has called for over time and was there in large print in Jobsback. That kind of labour market, which would be produced by that kind of outcome, by stripping away the safety nets, would certainly bring about much more of a US style disparity in terms of wage outcomes than we have known historically in this country. It would certainly bring about large numbers of working poor and large numbers of battlers. There would be a lot more battlers for a Liberal-National Party government to be concerned about.

We are at 27.3 per cent and the OECD countries on average are at 44.3 per cent.
—Is that good, Ralph?
—Order! The member for O'Connor!
—If you look at some particular countries, Germany is 46.8 per cent—Germany, which stands there as a country—
—So now we have a comparison.
—I warn the member for Mayo!

—representing the epitome of financial rectitude in most people's eyes, has a much higher level of government debt as a proportion of GDP than we have. The recent budget ensures that our debt will reduce considerably over the next four years. That is because we have moved to a budget surplus in 1995-96 with increasing surpluses over the out years—building from $700 million in 1995-96 to $7.4 billion in 1998-99. Those surpluses will lead to a reduction in Commonwealth general government debt by almost 30 per cent as a share of GDP, taking us down—this is the Commonwealth only—from 19.1 per cent of GDP to 13.7 per cent. These are very considerable reductions.

On current projections, general government debt for all levels of government in Australia will fall to 20 per cent of GDP by 1998-99—bearing in mind that the OECD average is currently 44 per cent. This would represent a very rapid reduction in public sector debt by international standards. The only other Western country looking at substantial debt reduction over the next few years is New Zealand. I think it is worth the House bearing in mind that New Zealand's revenue to GDP ratio for 1995-96 is 37.7 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much was that?

—It is 37.7 per cent, which is five per cent higher than the ratio in Australia for all levels of government—that is, tax revenue, as a proportion of GDP in New Zealand, is five per cent of GDP higher than in Australia. If Australia had a revenue to GDP ratio equal to that of New Zealand, we would be raising around $24 billion more revenue and we would have a budget surplus of $24 billion or five per cent of GDP. Of course, we would have taxes higher by $24 billion.

PARA.TAB: The government has obviously taken the view that we do not need to have taxes that high. Our revenue is already at a level which is enabling us to move, with the additions in the budget, to a position of surplus, and we will be moving into—as I have already mentioned—considerable debt reduction over the next few years.

I will conclude by saying that it is perhaps useful for the House to note that the European monetary union has established a set of convergence criteria which member countries have to satisfy before the process of monetary union can proceed—before they can move into the third stage. Those criteria currently are: that inflation should be less than 3 1/2 per cent; that bond yields should be below nine per cent; that a general government deficit should be less than three per cent of GDP; and gross public sector debt should be below 60 per cent of GDP.

There is only one European country that meets all those criteria at the present time—and that is Germany. Australia, however, does meet all those criteria. That, of course, indicates that we meet the standards of good governance established by the European Union for states wishing to move into the third stage—with a good performance on inflation, bond yields, general government deficits and public sector debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Treasurer and is an interesting follow-on from his answer to the last question. Does the Treasurer acknowledge that the Australian dollar has declined in value, in this year alone, by eight per cent against the US dollar, 10 per cent against the British pound, 11 per cent against the New Zealand dollar, 16 per cent against the German mark, and 22 per cent against the Japanese yen? Does this continual fall in the value of our currency not mean that the government's boast that it has built Australia's economic strength over the last 13 years is a myth?

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right! The member for McEwen!

—Is it not true that Australians are becoming poorer relative to the citizens of the other countries I have just mentioned? How do you explain your failure to Australians battling to keep their heads above water?
—It is the case that there has been a—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right! The member for Calare!

—It is the case that there has been a devaluation of the Australian dollar against all of the currencies that the honourable member mentioned in his question in the course of this year. That follows an appreciation against all of those currencies, except probably the Japanese yen in the latter half of last year.
—Ha, ha!
—We get idiotic laughter from the Leader of the Opposition. It is undoubtedly the case that there was that appreciation.
—Where was the dollar in 1983?

—There was that appreciation. What we have seen in the first half of this year is an unwinding of that appreciation. We have also seen most countries in the Western world—in fact all of them—devalue against the Japanese yen, so there is nothing particularly exceptional about that. The unwinding that has occurred this year is an unwinding against our appreciation last year plus the particular impact of the Japanese yen appreciation against everybody. The Japanese yen is of particular significance to us because it is so important to us on a trade weighted index, given Japan's importance as our No. 1 trading partner.

PARA.TAB: I do not think it is particularly helpful to enter into a discussion with the House about the future of the dollar, and I do not intend to do that. But I can say that the policies that have been put in place by the government are for the betterment of the Australian economy. We have policies which see us attacking savings to improve our savings performance in ways that I have already mentioned in answer to a previous question and which see us growing substantially with low inflation in a circumstance where market interest rates are declining. These are circumstances which are governing for the good of the country.

As I said in answer to the previous question, on the basis of the good governance criteria established by the European Union, we meet all of those criteria. Therefore, we are in a position where, despite adverse terms of trade and the drought, we are able to produce some fundamentally good economic performance. Our difficultly is in relation to the current account. The policies that have been put in place in relation to savings are fundamental to an attack on that. With the breaking of the drought and that approach to national savings, we are set fair for improvement in the current account in years to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. Is the minister aware of reports that the Western Australian Minister for Health, Mr Graham Kierath, has plans `to embark on a big campaign to shift health costs onto the federal government'? What is the government's response to these comments?

—I thank the member for Perth for his question. I did see those comments in this morning's paper. It is extraordinary, given the attitude of the other ministers at the health forum on Friday, how out of step Mr Kierath is. He has threatened `to embark on a big campaign to shift health costs onto the federal government' and he has threatened a showdown at high noon in Alice Springs next week unless the Commonwealth delivers. That is very much a confrontational and, I think, irresponsible approach that is at odds with the attitude taken by other ministers.

PARA.TAB: In the light of the Australian hospital care study, all of the other states have indicated that they want to work cooperatively with one another and with the Commonwealth. We have had an assessment of the effects of private health insurance changes on the state governments and also the extent to which they have engaged in cost shifting to date. What was seen from the Western Australian minister, although he did hear some of the discussion of ministers via telephone, was a typical shoot from the hip reaction which we have come to expect of that government in Western Australia—the cowboy actions of a cowboy government, its eyes off the ball again, out of step with the rest of country and increasingly erratic in the way it conducts its affairs.

Any move by the WA health minister along the lines that he has outlined to promote cost shifting will certainly backfire. I would like to draw his attention not only to the fact that the Commonwealth provides very substantial funding to the states under Medicare to enable them to provide a comprehensive range of public hospital in-patient and out-patient services but also to the fact that we will adjust the hospital funding grants if they cost shift to that extent, and that is listed in this year's budget.

More than that, the particular arrangement that Mr Kierath points to would result in doctors being prosecuted. They would be in breach of the respective Commonwealth acts. We intend to take very firm action indeed against any states, individual public hospitals or doctors who cost shift to the Commonwealth in that way, using provider numbers inappropriately and illegally.

Mr Kierath says that he is interested in Western Australians and does not want them to suffer. I must say that I have not noticed that in any of his previous policies. Let us look at the facts which surround the claim that he is interested in their wellbeing. First of all, the Western Australian government should particularly look at its very dismal record on health expenditure to find the real causes of the problems. For example—and I will table the appropriate graph—in 1993-94, its first full year in government, state funding for hospitals from its own sources fell by 20.6 per cent in real terms. It took $100 million out of Western Australian hospitals. The minister has the temerity to suggest that he is going to shift costs onto the Commonwealth. It has already removed them.

It is very clear that Mr Kierath either does not know what is happening in his own budget or simply refuses to acknowledge it. I think that what he is actually doing is shaping up for the upcoming budget because all the signs are that the state government intends to cut funding further. We have seen a 20-odd per cent reduction in funding from the state government in the face of a 31 per cent increase in Commonwealth funding. This in one draw and out the bottom draw policy is apparently going to be exacerbated under this new minister.

This is an environment where Western Australia is growing rapidly and its revenue is growing rapidly, yet the government there is prepared to penalise hospital funding in that state. Taxes are going up as well. This is very cynical and tawdry politics and is very much at odds with the views of all the other health ministers. I point out that, far from being innocent of this practice, Western Australia has already attempted to cost shift by threatening last year to close down the radiation oncology unit at Royal Perth Hospital and pass on the costs, at that stage, to the consumers and the Commonwealth. Fortunately, we heard about this and the Commonwealth stepped in directly. We are now providing funding to enable a continuing radiation oncology service in one of our major teaching hospitals in Western Australia. In that case, arrangements are in place to recoup any additional Medicare benefit schedule outlays.

I call on that minister to withdraw those charges and make sure that his actions do not actually result in doctors being charged and their tax records perhaps being examined as a result. If they are using their provider numbers and claiming income that is not theirs, I am sure that there will be other people interested in this matter besides the health minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moylan Mrs J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. In answer to a question on 30 November last year, you said that the government's reduction in company tax to 33c was `done with an eye to structural change' which was `to provide some longer term encouragement to investment'. You further stated:

QUESTION.PARA: So I don't think it would be a case of simply saying, `Well, now the economy is growing we can rip all that away'.
Is the increase in company tax announced in the budget not reversing that structural change?
Why should any battling small business believe anything you say when you are doing precisely what you said you would not do—`rip all that away'?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not ripping all that away. Let us look at the history of company tax since we have been in office. When the now Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer he had a company tax rate of 46 per cent. Under us that rate was increased at one stage to 49 per cent, but in the context of there being full imputation for dividends. The Leader of the Opposition had a 46 per cent rate and double taxation of dividends. We increased that rate to 49 per cent, but in the context of bringing in full imputation. We took away double taxation of dividends.

PARA.TAB: That was a major boost to shareholders in this country and a major attraction for people to invest in equities. We then moved to reduce that rate to 39 per cent and then, later on, to 33 per cent. There have been major steps taken in the area of company tax to reduce the rate by some 13 per cent below what it was when we came into office and to remove the double taxation of dividends. In addition, the investment allowance, brought in as a temporary stimulus to investment—nevertheless, with the effect of cutting effective company tax rates—the development allowance and the 150 per cent write-off capacity in research and development, which is an increasing attraction for companies to undertake research and development and reduces their effective company tax rate, have been very stimulatory for companies in this country.

In this budget we have increased the company tax rate by three per cent, which takes it back to 36 per cent, but it is not, as the questioner implied, a reversal of the previous decision. We made that decision to take it back to 36 per cent as a means of saying that, in terms of the current need for us to increase revenue, the best and obvious place to look is to those areas where major concessions have been given in the context of the recession and its aftermath. Clearly, companies have been given that substantial benefit.

As also mentioned in the question, we are concerned to have a structural change in company tax for competitive reasons. When we reduced it from 39 per cent to 33 per cent, we had an eye on the rates in other OECD countries and in the region. Clearly, in looking at the possibility of increasing that rate again, we were concerned not to move too far away from the rate of 33 per cent because of those competitive factors.

The movement up to 36 per cent still leaves us in the competitive range, particularly in the context of there being full imputation still applying in this country. We are one of the few countries in the developed world that gives full imputation for company tax. That is still there 100 per cent. The other allowances, such as the developmental allowance, are still there. The investment allowance is now starting to phase out but it is still affecting levels of company tax being paid.

There is no ripping away of the benefit, as mentioned by the questioner. The fact is there was some reversal of that decision but only a partial reversal. In looking at the need for there to be fiscal tightening in this country, it is appropriate for companies who have high levels of profits, and had major concessions on their company tax rates effectively, to bear some of the burden of that increased need for fiscal tightening. In the circumstances that we face, the decision taken is thoroughly reasonable. There has not been a great deal of complaint from the corporate sector about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen proposals for a commission of audit into the Commonwealth's financial position? What is the Treasurer's response to those proposals? Is it intended that those proposals will be adopted?

—I thank the member for Werriwa for his question. I have seen a proposal for a commission of audit from a Mr Des Moore in a publication last February from the Institute of Public Affairs. Mr Moore proposed the establishment of an audit commission as part of a proposal to cut Commonwealth government expenditure by $15 billion to $16 billion. He said that such a commission would comprise a panel of independent people, such as himself no doubt, to evaluate Commonwealth expenditure. Mr Moore is full of ideas as to what such a commission could recommend.
—Why are you attacking him?
—In his view, massive savings could be made in government expenditure.
—Michael, stop him, please! It is quite personal.
—I warn the member for O'Connor!

—He suggests the following: an 11.8 per cent cut in social security, a 13.4 per cent cut in health, a 39 per cent cut in labour and employment, a 43 per cent cut in housing and community amenities, and a 66 per cent cut in culture and recreation. They are the sorts of broad cuts he envisages in order to get $15 billion to $16 billion out of this commission of audit.

PARA.TAB: In social security, he proposes a 12-month limit on unemployment benefits to save about $1 billion. So after one year on those benefits you will receive no more benefits—saving about $1 billion. On the age pension, he proposes to end the automatic indexation. So, apart from an odd one every now and again if you felt like it, there would be no more indexation. He also proposes that eligibility for the age pension be raised from 65 years to 70 years. On child care, he proposes to do away with means tested fee relief and have a regressive 25 per cent tax rebate to save $500 million.

He also proposes the following: for health services, a $5 per visit charge to the doctor to save a billion dollars; in public hospitals, a full charge for the first day's treatment to save $460 million; the abolition of the general system of pharmaceutical subsidies to save $434 million; for education, reduce the number of beneficiaries of Austudy by 100,000 to save $300 million; on culture, sell the ABC and end taxpayer funded film finance to save $79 million, phase out the Australia Council; and cut out government expenditure on sport and recreation and so on. That is the kind of agenda that Mr Moore said would be possible through a commission of audit.

I can assure the member for Werriwa that the government does not intend to adopt Mr Moore's proposal. We already have one of the smallest public sectors amongst developed countries. Because it is well targeted, we have been able, nevertheless, to ensure that we have an adequate social wage which provides substantial support for people on lower and middle incomes. As the Minister for Social Security said in question time yesterday, the social wage has been greatly increased under this government, with a 75 per cent real increase per capita under us compared with a 17 1/2 per cent decline under the previous government when the current Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer.

I have noticed that the establishment of a commission of audit has been proposed by the opposition since February, by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in his post-budget speech at the National Press Club. In proposing this commission of audit, the opposition is following a well worn track of Liberal oppositions at the state level in this country. They have done it in New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia and South Australia. In every case, it has been used as a device to hide their real intentions to impose swingeing cuts in government expenditure and to increase taxes. In other words, they have said, `We can't tell you what we are going to do. We will have this commission of audit. When we have the commission of audit—from independent people, of course—we will know exactly what we are going to do.' In each case, it has resulted in these swingeing cuts in expenditure and increased taxes.

So it would be in this case. If the Leader of the Opposition were being really honest with the Australian people in his so-called headland speech tonight, the speech would probably be called `Cape Tribulation' for the great affliction it would impose on the Australian people—especially on the so-called battlers whom the opposition so cynically claims to represent.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Has the minister examined six recommendations on the work required of a Commonwealth commission of audit? What do these recommendations entail? Is the government intending to implement them?

—In response to the honourable member, I have seen six recommendations on the task for a commission of audit. It was contained in that speech plagiarising Des Moore by the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, when he got up, as the one policy announcement, the one proposition that he put forward as his response to the federal budget. He wrapped himself in the cloak that he loves to wrap himself in of deep knowledge of the budgeting processes of the Commonwealth. Naturally, one would be tremendously impressed. Naturally, all things are new that he proposes. Naturally, the government, of course, has failed to implement any of the suggestions that have been put forward—which are, after all, just the list he got from Des Moore of commonsense propositions in terms of accounting processes as opposed to his `uncommon' sense propositions in terms of what cuts he wanted to put in place.

PARA.TAB: Let us take a look at each of them so that I can settle in his own mind that there is no requirement for his occasional night reading in this regard. `The first task for the commission of audit,' he said, `will be to identify the contingent liabilities of the Commonwealth, including public service superannuation.'

Perhaps he might like to refer back to the statements made by my predecessor as Minister for Finance which established accrual accounting as the basis of Commonwealth reporting for Commonwealth departments from this point on, and note that all Commonwealth departments from this point on are doing precisely that. Perhaps he might also like to have a look at the actuarial reports on superannuation liabilities of the Commonwealth superannuation and public sector schemes, the Defence Force retirement and death benefits and the military super and benefit schemes which were tabled in parliament in June 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Auditor-General said he would not name the liabilities, you dropped him.
—Order! The Minister for Finance will wait.
—He does not know what he is talking about so I always enjoy his interjections.
—No, you will wait for a minute. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition does get some grace in this place by virtue of his position; and it is starting to wear a touch thin.

—Grace in this place from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was not a term I would have chosen to use, Mr Speaker, but nevertheless I would not quarrel with you. As to the impacts of demographic change on Commonwealth outlays and how to make provision for them, I should just suggest that he read through the budget statements as they go through, for example, all the family policies that we have put in place, the assessments which are placed on where we see the development of families going, the $12.6 billion that are put in to deal with their problems.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps he might even move on from that and take a look at the superannuation propositions associated with the budget, and listen perhaps to the statements we have been making about the ageing of the population, the impact that that has on health, the impact that that has on potential liabilities of the Commonwealth in the years out there in regard to the old age pension, and start to acknowledge the fact that we are addressing it and he is not.

Then he goes on and says `the preparation of a full Commonwealth balance sheet'. As he would know from having seen those statements on the movement of all departments to accrual based accounting, the Commonwealth is in the process of preparing balance sheets which do precisely that.

He also says `the state of the Commonwealth infrastructure and the private and public measures required to restore it to the levels required for the next decade'. He should look at the EPAC report. EPAC has reported, in draft form, into the Commonwealth on where it sees infrastructure spending going. EPAC is seeking comments prior to presenting a full report on that later this year.

He then says `the financial performance targets for Commonwealth departments'. Virtually all areas of budget now do that, as a result of moving over to accrual accounting. Then he says `the level of duplication between Commonwealth and the states in the delivery of services and measures to promote more efficient delivery'. He should ring up all his colleagues from the various state bureaucracies. There has now been undertaken for some considerable time, associated with COAG, a roles and responsibility review on precisely these matters. I can give him a figure if he is actually looking to this to provide him with some area of comfort as to whether or not there is a costly overlap which might produce a saving.

My department, on the examination it has made so far on this, announced a while ago that it sees a saving in running costs of some $30 million in this area. That is about $30 million associated with a number of Commonwealth bureaucrats overseeing the distribution of resources. Given the answer made by the minister for health, I am not at all sure we can afford to lose those bureaucrats and the running costs that are associated with them, given the performance the states are starting to show up on attempts to shift to the Commonwealth the cost of their own obligations.

He has clothed himself in this set of propositions, which were supposed to make him look like an economically responsible opposition spokesman—a man with a plan when he gets himself into office. Every single proposition he put forward was covered off years ago by the Commonwealth. If it was not covered off years ago, it is in the process of implementation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I ask my question on behalf of Mr Lu of Mirrabooka, an area of battlers that has been savaged by your government. Mr Lu signed a contract to have a home built on 3 May this year. He moved out of his present home to sell, and rented a house while waiting for his new home to be built. —I think you should tell Mr Lu to be thankful that the coalition is not in government, as he would be wearing a 15 per cent GST on his house. This is a minor extension of tax in relation to building materials, a tax of 12 per cent on a small additional number of items, compared with the 15 per cent tax that the coalition would have imposed, were it in government, on all building materials, including all those not taxed by the government. This includes all of the main structural items like the bricks, the roofing tiles, the cement, the gravel, the walls, the doors and the windows. PARA.TAB: I think you should tell Mr Lu to be very thankful that the government is in office, because if the Liberal and National parties were in office he would be paying much higher taxes than he will be paying with this extension of tax on building materials, which is of a minor nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Is he aware of concerns that the national competition policy threatens local government and the delivery of essential community services? How is the government proposing to address those concerns?

—I thank the member for Calare for his question. When all governments signed up to the national competition policy in April, we all agreed to publish policy statements on the implementation of the competition principles agreement by June of next year. In other words, we all agreed to lay out a blueprint of what we would be doing individually to achieve a more competitive economy and to ensure that competition serves the public interest.

PARA.TAB: The protection of the public interest and the delivery of community service obligations, or CSOs, are just as important as the drive for efficiency. As I said last week, those state governments which are rushing to privatise—and that is not part of the competition agenda—should be taking the time to read their agreement carefully and to spell out how they will be delivering their CSOs into the future.

I am aware of concerns that community service obligations are under threat, that the disadvantaged may suffer with the removal of concessional pricing of water and electricity unless governments have effective CSO policies in place. Unlike the states, the federal government has policies on CSOs and, might I say, a proud record of delivering them. We have introduced competition but retained the universal telephone access and the standard letter rate across Australia. State governments need to spell out how they will be looking after their disadvantaged citizens and they need to spell out how they will be delivering their CSOs into the future.

Each state government also has to consult with local government on how these reforms will apply to them. I note that members of the National Party in particular have been going around to local government authorities scaring them, such as the member for Maranoa, who said in a press clipping, `Reforms could hasten the death of rural communities.' The only thing that will hasten the death of rural communities is headlines like this that are generated by scaremongering or if state governments do not accept their responsibilities.

To assist governments develop their detailed implementation statements, I have sent a reference to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, whose chairman asked me this question. I will be asking that committee to look at the application of the public interest tests. I will be asking it to have a look at the implications for federal government. I will also be asking it to see how governments are currently delivering community service obligations and to look at options for ensuring that they continue to be delivered efficiently into the future.

I am looking to the inquiry to provide firm guidance on how the economically and socially disadvantaged can be assured of access to basic services such as electricity and water just as we provide access to the postal and telecommunications systems, while the community as a whole receives the benefits of the competition policy package. I wish his committee well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Attorney-General. I refer him to the Senate budget estimates committee meeting of last week when his department refused to provide details even of the nature of complaints taken by Australian citizens to three United Nations committees. I remind the Attorney-General that the officers of his department refused to provide the information to the parliament until they had checked with the United Nations committee. Did Australia end appeals to the Privy Council to ensure the independence of the Australian legal system? Why has your government now abrogated Australian sovereignty by denying information to the Australian parliament without first getting permission from a United Nations committee?

—I think the honourable member is referring to complaints made under the First Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which allow Australian citizens to make complaints to the Human Rights Committee of the United Nations. This is the process which led to the Toonen complaint and the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill, which no doubt the honourable member recalls quite well.

PARA.TAB: The standard requirement which this particular optional protocol calls for is to respect the privacy of the individuals who make complaints to the UN committee. Given that there are many regimes in the world where a complaint against the government by a citizen may lead to some unfortunate consequences to that citizen, one can understand why there may be such a requirement imposed by this particular optional protocol.

I did become aware of the questioning of the departmental officers in relation to the disclosure of the general nature of the complaints. I have in fact advised my department that I did not think the response given by the officers was satisfactory. I believe that the Senate committee and, indeed, the parliament are entitled to be given certainly outline material as to the nature of the complaint, obviously respecting the privacy of the individual. I will ensure that happens.

Would he advise the House about any actions the government may be taking to support this decision? Would the Minister also inform the House what progress has been made in implementing the parliament's decision to award the ABC a licence for two pay TV channels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lee The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ABC agreed to establish Australia Television for three years as a condition of receiving $5.4 million from the government in 1992. It is no surprise, I am sure, to the honourable member for Leichhardt and to members on this side of the House that the ABC board should be looking at the future of Australia Television since we are now reaching the end of the period covered by agreement between the government and the ABC to provide the Australia Television service.

PARA.TAB: After reviewing Australia Television's revenue and expenditure, the ABC board considered a number of options at its meeting last week, on 31 May. Professor Armstrong, the chairman of the ABC, has advised me that at this stage the ABC board has decided to continue the Australia Television service.
