DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The failure of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to administer the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 in a fair, just and transparent way.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this matter of public importance debate, let us first of all be clear about what is under discussion. It is not Aboriginal heritage, it is not Professor Cheryl Saunders and it is not Doreen Kartinyeri; it is the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) and his responsibility as minister for the fair and just administration of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act and for what he has done, as a consequence of his action, to Aboriginal heritage.

PARA.TAB: The first question, Minister, is: did you consider the evidence before you made your judgment on Hindmarsh Island, or is it true that you made up your mind irrespective of the evidence? Minister, did you ever have it in your mind not to ban the bridge? There were 400 representations, none of which you saw and none of which your staff member could have read in the short time that was available to her. Indeed, Justice O'Loughlin found that you had not considered the evidence. His judgment states:

SPEECH.PARA: But, in my opinion, the evidence that had been placed before the court in these proceedings has shown, as a matter of probability, that the Minister did not give any "consideration" to the representations at all.

Minister, you said you made up your mind on the Saturday morning, 9 July, to ban the Hindmarsh Island bridge. What evidence do we have that you made your mind up after considering all the evidence? We have none, because you have produced none. But we have lots of evidence to suggest that you had already made up your mind before the Saturday.

PARA.TAB: First of all, there is the fax on 7 July to the Office of Legislative Drafting confirming that the declaration would be for 25 years. It is true that Justice O'Loughlin has considered this, but let us consider it a little bit further, shall we? How on 7 July, if you did not make up your mind until 9 July, could your office fax to the draftsperson that the declaration would be for 25 years? Presumably, Minister, because declarations are usually for 25 years. Is that true? Minister, when we go back to your previous two declarations, what do we find? Twenty years and five years. So, if this was just a draft declaration in case you had to make it, why did we not go by past precedents?

There is something else. Is it not true that ATSIC had recommended a ban for four years on this Hindmarsh Island issue on 7 July? Here we have previous declarations made for 20 and five years, ATSIC recommends four; and what does the minister do: he puts out a draft that says the declaration will be for 25 years. This is somebody who has not made up his mind. Did he ask for two drafts, one maybe for five or 10 and one for 25? No, just the one for 25. That is the first piece of evidence.

Second, there are I believe five statutory declarations—and I am sure another member could produce the three if you would like them tabled—which state that on Friday night, 8 July, at an Aboriginal ball a statement was made that the Hindmarsh Island bridge would be stopped, the information coming either from you or from your office. How could that announcement be made at an Aboriginal ball if you had not conveyed that information? Was the person who said it not telling the truth? Why would anybody get up in front of a ball and say that if it were not the truth? There are five statutory declarations. The person supposed to have made the declaration has not denied it—and funny, Minister, I have not really heard you deny it.

Next, we have the conversation with Dean Brown—do you remember that?—last Thursday. That was the absolute proof. You said Dean Brown knew that you had not made up your mind at 10 o'clock on the Saturday morning. But what do we find?

TALK.START.PARA: —`Had' or `had not'—which one is this?

—That you had told this parliament that you had not made up your mind on 10 July at 10 a.m., or close to 10 a.m., when you spoke to the Premier. That was your defence on Thursday to the allegations made against you. What did Premier Dean Brown say? He said, `I was so convinced that the minister had made up his mind that I called the Prime Minister and tried to speak to him.' So much for Thursday's defence. In conclusion, you made up your mind before seeing the evidence. In fact, you had never any other intention but to ban the bridge.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at something even a little more serious than this, and that is the declaration itself. When we look at the declaration, the story becomes curiouser and curiouser. First of all, we have the declaration that you are to sign faxed from your Canberra office to your home in Sydney. It is faxed there. You get the fax and you sign it with your signature to send it back.

What happens to this fax in your home, Minister? It has disappeared. It has been suggested that the baby ate it. Is this the way you conduct your official business? Do you have a dog? If you have a dog, do we conclude that the dog could have eaten it as well? An official fax disappears from your home. What is more, there is not one fax log record to show what time that fax arrived. What happens next? The minister has signed it, then it gets lost. But it is faxed before it is lost back to the Canberra office with the date and time on it. This is the second record. We have lost the first; now we have got a record as it goes back to the Canberra office. What does the Canberra office do with it? It cuts the top off it. Minister, do you always cut the tops off your faxes?

TALK.START.PARA: —Every day.

—Every day. I will tell you when you cut the tops off your faxes, Minister: it is when somebody asks you to disguise something. This is not just an ordinary fax. Minister, you are aware that you are talking here about a $175 million deal, the developers are talking litigation and you have discussed the litigation with the Prime Minister. So you know what is at stake, but your office cuts the tops off the faxes. You then fax the mutilated copy off to the Gazette. What does your office then do with that fax it has just faxed off? It loses it. It loses the next fax. The lawyers asked for it, appealed for evidence, and no-one can find it. ATSIC does not have it; you do not have it; and your office does not have it.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I seek to draw your attention to the fact that the member for Hindmarsh has, from the beginning of her presentation, repeatedly spoken directly to the minister instead of speaking through you.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—I remind the member for Hindmarsh to address her remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us have a look at the minister's next fax. ATSIC does not have it; the minister does not have it; the minister's office does not have it; and we presume the baby does not have it—we are only assuming also that the dog does not have it. So what do we have here? At the very best interpretation, we have a sloppy minister who runs a very sloppy office and, at the worst, a deliberate attempt to destroy the only means by which we can establish the timing of the decision making process. We have three fax catastrophes—and I remind you that Lady Bracknell said that one mistake is unfortunate; two is careless. Why should we not conclude that three is deliberate? Let us have a look at your defences.
—Order! The honourable member will address her remarks through the chair.

—Let us have a look at the minister's defences. His first defence was that his office cut the top off the faxes because they were to be camera-ready. That is not how I make faxes camera-ready. I photocopy them and tidy them up. Indeed, Minister, is this not what they had to do at the Gazette anyway to insert a map in the middle of the declaration? Your second defence is that Justice O'Loughlin—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a further point of order. I must insist that the procedure in this chamber be pursued by the person speaking—that is, that member speak through the chair.
—Order! The honourable member for Hindmarsh will address her remarks through the chair.
—The minister's second defence is that Justice O'Loughlin had cleared him. But Justice O'Loughlin said:

SPEECH.PARA: The consequence of these findings is the conclusion that there has been a fundamental failure by the Minister to comply with the statutory obligation that he consider the representations before deciding whether to exercise his power to make a declaration under section 10 of the Commonwealth Heritage Act.

So much for that defence. Then there was Dean Brown, but we know what happened to that defence. We also have the minister's statement that the case is under appeal. Is it not true that the reason the case is under appeal has nothing to do with any of the things we have discussed? That is a particularly spurious defence. The fourth defence is probably the most pathetic of all—that is, in attacking the minister the coalition is attacking Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: Next, Minister, we have your failure and refusal to look at the contradictory evidence. Surely, it is important for the minister that, when Aboriginal people rediscover their traditions and culture that have been lost through dispossession, forced resettlement and migration, they discover the truth. To suggest otherwise is to debase those traditions and that culture.

Any person interested in the truth and anyone concerned with the integrity of Aboriginal culture and its preservation would surely want such claims investigated. Yet an investigation has been denied, even condemned, by you, Minister. To dismiss the concerns of Dorothy and Dulcie Wilson, Bertha Gollan and other senior Aboriginal women as unimportant and irrelevant must be one of the strangest sleights of hand perpetuated by a minister who claims to support all Aboriginal people.

Under the guise of supporting Aboriginal people, you have taken sides and you have deliberately disempowered one group of Aboriginal women. Certainly, Dorothy Wilson must be today contemplating the high personal cost she has had to pay. She might ask: why is the minister not prepared to speak out against her vilification? Why is he so silent about what has happened to the most defenceless of Aboriginal people? What does the minister suggest is her motive for speaking out—money, glory, fame? Perhaps, Minister, it is the desire for truth.

I make no judgment about the truth as Dorothy Wilson believes it or as Doreen Kartinyeri believes it, and neither should you, Minister. The real tragedy of the whole Hindmarsh Island debacle for Aboriginal people is that, without an investigation that settles the controversy one way or another, this confusion and these contradictory stories can be exploited elsewhere to cast doubts on Aboriginal heritage issues.

The cause of Aboriginal people can only be served by the truth. It is because truth was abandoned in favour of political expediency that myths such as terra nullius were perpetuated. In getting rid of past lives, let us not fall into the trap of adopting a process that would allow us to perpetuate new ones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —All over Australia Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are quivering in their boots at the prospect that the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) might one day assume the office of Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. The fact is that on every single occasion that the coalition has a choice between defending the heritage values of indigenous Australians and supporting other interests—whether they be developers or someone else—the coalition supports the bulldozer above the rights of indigenous people. We have seen a tawdry track record from the coalition in dealing with this Hindmarsh Island bridge issue within the parliament and outside the parliament. In the course of my remarks, I am going to say something about the opposition's conduct in dealing with that issue.

PARA.TAB: First of all, let me put on the public record that my actions in this matter, in issuing the declaration to protect the area from desecration, have been supported by no lesser authority than the Commonwealth parliament. Both houses of the Commonwealth parliament have endorsed my actions and have refused to support the disallowance motion moved and supported by the coalition in both houses. I can say to indigenous people that, when I speak, I speak with the support of the parliament. They ought not to think that because the coalition in this place refuses to stand up for their interests the rest of us do not care about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage and are not prepared to speak out and stand up for what is right.

I want to pose a challenge to any member of this House, any member of the press gallery or any member of the public to read the judgment of Justice O'Loughlin in relation to the heritage declaration and, as appropriate, read the transcript of the court case that gave rise to the judgment. I want to say that, almost without exception, every single issue that has been canvassed extensively by really only two major media outlets—the Adelaide Advertiser and Network Ten—and by a few columnists like Piers Ackerman, was received, considered and rejected by Justice O'Loughlin.

I will give you five or six examples of the slurs that have been issued against me and against indigenous people in this matter and the way they were independently considered by the court and rejected. I stand here on the floor of the parliament with the support of the parliament having gone through a judicial inquiry. I have been there. My actions have been before the court, scrutinised to the most minute detail and I have walked through that process and emerged with my integrity intact and my actions in respect of the matters challenged by the coalition vindicated by no less an authority than the Federal Court of Australia.

I will take members through some issues. One issue that has been raised in the media is that I issued a declaration for a different period than that recommended in advice to me. Yes, this is true, but this is also a matter that has been considered by the Federal Court of Australia. Mr Justice O'Loughlin made it clear that the decision maker in this matter was not some bureaucrat and not some staff member but me as the relevant federal minister. It was my decision. How did I issue a declaration different to some of the advice put to me by some of the bureaucrats? I had regard to the Saunders report. If you look at the Saunders report, you will see that she did not support a declaration for a limited period.

For days on end we have had this slur against former members of my staff—people who are not in a position to defend themselves and who have gone on to other careers—that somehow or other they mutilated documents to destroy evidence. That was raised in front of Mr Justice O'Loughlin. Every word and every minute detail on the timing and date on which faxes were sent and how documents were dealt with was raised in front of Mr Justice O'Loughlin. Every single scrap of evidence that has been hurled publicly by some of the columnists in the Adelaide Advertiser and by some of those on Network Ten has been raised in the Federal Court. What did Mr Justice O'Loughlin decide? He decided that I had not prejudged the matter. He decided that that evidence was not to be supported.

It has been alleged in the course of public debate on this issue and supported by the coalition that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in some way provided improper advice to the applicants in this matter. Mr Justice O'Loughlin considered that too. As the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) ought to know and certainly the member for Hindmarsh ought to know, he rejected any impropriety on the part of ATSIC.

It has been said consistently that I prejudged this matter. All this nonsense that I somehow predetermined the matter was argued like Blue Hills in the Federal Court. It went on for hours and hours. Members of my staff were cross-examined. What did the judge say? The judge said that I had behaved properly in this matter. It was alleged in no lesser an authority than the Adelaide Advertiser, I think on Saturday, that the fact that I had caused the preparation of a draft declaration was somehow prejudging the matter.

Mr Justice O'Loughlin considered this and he said that I had behaved prudently. He made it clear that I was working to a tight time frame. If the South Australian Premier had said to me, `Look Robert, we will have a cooling off period. We will call off the threat,' then things might have been a bit different. But that was not what it was about. My best recollection of what the judge said in relation to this matter was that it would be a dereliction of my duty if I did not act in such a way as to ensure that there was no gap between the expiry of a section 9 declaration and the issue of a section 10 declaration. He said that I used a prudent course of action in ensuring the preparation of a draft declaration.

The Adelaide Advertiser knew all that. If Colin James, who I understand has won a Walkley award for his efforts, keeps going the way he is going he should send back the award. This guy knew when he wrote the story that the court had expressly considered this matter, yet the Adelaide Advertiser put this on the front page of its paper.

Another accusation has been made by journalist Geoff Easdowne who most of the time wrote all of his stories without even bothering to talk to my office. If I recall the article appropriately, he said that somehow or other I had ignored legal advice with respect to compensation. I have done nothing of the sort. Read what Justice O'Loughlin said about my actions in this matter. He said that I was a prudent minister and that I cared about the taxpayers. Read what a judge of the Federal Court of Australia said.

There are some other matters I wish to raise in the course of this debate, but one thing that I would like to say is: is it not extraordinary that whenever there is an opportunity for the coalition to exploit a political issue then respect for the independence of the judiciary and the judicial process go out the window? You are supposed to be the upholders of the traditional views in this country. You are supposed to be the upholders of standards of propriety and ethics.

We are talking about a case that is still before the Federal Court of Australia. What we have seen from what I have already said is a conspiracy between a number of key members of the Liberal Party and, I believe, the solicitors for the Chapmans. Some members of the media have either been conned into being a part of this or have been unwittingly used as stooges in this. What they have done through a series of newspaper stories is re-run the arguments expressly rejected by the Federal Court of Australia.

I will say some things when I am ready about the nature of conduct that has gone on behind the scenes and the way this has been run. I happen to believe that the member for Mayo (Mr Downer), despite the fact that we have disagreed on some things, is, in a number of respects, an honourable man. I ask him to read the judgment of the Federal Court and look at the evidence.

I saw what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said when asked about the conduct of the member for Barker. A journalist said to him, `If you got someone's private documents, you would deal with them the same way, wouldn't you?' The Prime Minister said no. Of course he would not. I would not either. Do you think that if we happened to be in opposition I would do what you have done in respect of these assertions and re-run this court case?

TALK.START.PARA: —Daryl Melham did.

—That is an entirely different story. I will tell you the difference. Firstly, the document in question was a single page and this was eight kilograms of documents. Secondly, the document in question did not relate to a current court case. Thirdly, it was a highly political document. There are a number of other key distinguishing factors. This was a case of misdirected, highly confidential, private mail that contained legal documents.

PARA.TAB: Let us judge the difference between the standards of the shadow Attorney-General, whom we do not always agree with, and the member for Barker. One thing that the member for Barker can be sure of is that when you are down and you are troubled, as the song says, you have got a friend. Your friend is the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). No matter what you do and what you have done in respect of this matter—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The minister will address his remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course. The Leader of the Opposition has nailed his colours to the mast in respect of this matter. The colours that he has nailed to the mast are not those of the shadow Attorney-General; they are those of the member for Barker. He has put in writing, despite all his atrocities, that his respect for the member for Barker remains undiminished.

PARA.TAB: In the limited time available to me I want to turn to some more general matters raised by the widely drafted matter of public importance, but which have not been addressed in the course of the remarks made by the shadow minister. She has been critical of my administration of the federal legislation—not the Hindmarsh Island bridge issue but generally. I want to say something to this House about the approach that I bring to bear in dealing with that legislation.

I am deeply conscious of the responsibilities that I have, as the federal minister, in dealing with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Heritage Protection Act. I have incredibly onerous responsibilities and they weigh heavily on my shoulders now as they always have done in my time in this office. I do have to balance competing interests, but I am also guided by courts in how I administer the act. In the case of Bropho and Tickner there is very clear guidance to me about key aspects of how I administer the act.

While I have been administering this legislation, I have always tried to bring about mediated or negotiated arrangements to settle matters. I particularly refer to the Broome crocodile farm; the Strehlow collection; and my efforts—even in the face of all the warnings from the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), who told me it was literally an impossible task—to work with the Northern Territory government to resolve the Northern Territory-Alice Springs dam issue. In all those matters, I tried to operate in a way to bring people together.

I ask the people who might read the Hansard to consider the way I have administered the act. Have I appointed some lackeys, some people who are best friends or close allies of the Labor Party, in calling for reports as I am obliged to do under the legislation? I appointed Fred Chaney for goodness sake. I appointed a former judge of the Supreme Court of New South Wales, Hal Wootten. I would have thought that Professor Cheryl Saunders was a very eminent Australian for whom we would all have regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is she married to a Labor minister?

—If you do not believe me about the independence, competency and integrity of Professor Saunders, read the judgment of Justice O'Loughlin because he praises her independence and integrity. That is the general philosophy I have sought to bear in respect of the administration of the act.

PARA.TAB: Let me conclude on this note. Here we stand in the run-down to a federal election. What area of public policy is significant for the coalition to address among key issues of public policy as we go to the election? It would have to be Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, which led to the member for Mayo perishing as the Leader of the Opposition. But it is eight months since the member for Hindmarsh promised the public that she would come forward with a policy in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. It has been eight months since the former policy sank in the deserts of central Australia. Eight months later, we have not heard one word of policy. We do not even know whether those opposite would support the continued existence of the federal legislation.

I hope this debate will close this matter. If it does not close this matter, if you want to keep coming at me, I can assure you I will keep coming back at you with the truth as I have at all times. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) has asked us to look at Justice O'Loughlin's judgment. We should do that because Justice O'Loughlin overturned the minister's declaration. In doing so, he said a number of things. One was that the minister had failed `to properly consider the representations that were made to him'.

PARA.TAB: I remind everybody in this House that section 10 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Act says that the minister should have taken notice of those representations. He also said that, `as a matter of probability, the minister did not give any consideration to the representations at all'.

The minister has asked us in this House to look at that judgment. We are looking at that judgment. I might also remind him, and I am not particularly critical of her, that Justice O'Loughlin said that his senior adviser's evidence was vague and nebulous. In answering a couple of those rather general justifications, the minister gave—

TALK.START.PARA: —What did he say about Cheryl Saunders?

—We will get to that. This minister is the man with no answers. Our shadow minister, the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), is right. Did the minister's office give instructions to ATSIC to change the declaration from four years to 25 years? If the minister's office did give instructions to ATSIC the day before the declaration was issued, why was it worded that the declaration will be for 25 years? Why was there no `if'?

PARA.TAB: The minister is going to go out of here because he will not answer any of these questions. That just shows that he is sure short of the stuff in the middle of the stomach—absolutely gutless. The first point is that the instruction for declaration said, `You will issue that declaration for 25 years and you will put a map on the declaration.'

The next matter I wish to raise is that the minister said he made the declaration on Saturday, 9 July. All the evidence, he says, points that way. However, Premier Brown rang him on the morning of 9 July, and the phone call finished at about 11.08 Eastern Standard Time. Talk about giving somebody a cooling-off period! After the Premier of the state had given his best view, the minister gave him a cooling-off period of seven minutes. He then rang up his adviser and said, `Make the declaration.' The truth of the matter is that he made that decision days before. Everybody knows that he made it days before, including Mrs Doreen Kartinyeri who announced it at a ball in Adelaide the previous night. It is absolute nonsense for the minister to get up here and say that those things had not been done.

I want to take this minister not only to the matter I have just raised, or to the matter of the auto scissors cutting the top of the fax off, or to the matter that he has a whiteboard fax machine which manages to dispose of faxes either into the nappy or out with the baby's bathwater, but also to the very fact that this matter started back on 9 May because some men from the Lower Murray Aboriginal Heritage Committee asked 15 Ngarrindjeri women from Murray Bridge to come to a meeting. The purpose of the meeting was because, in their view, the report done by anthropologist Neale Draper—and the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) has a copy of that report, she was quoting from it here in November; I do not have a copy but she has—was not good enough for them to get a declaration made. That was the purpose of the meeting.

So they invited 15 women along and said, `We've got a lady called Doreen Kartinyeri and she is going to tell you what the women's business is about.' She told them that Hindmarsh Island was a place where white men's babies had been aborted and so forth. So they wrote a letter to the minister on that basis without describing the exactitude of that. They went to the other side of the island and the people from the Aboriginal legal movement said, `That's not good enough.' So they wrote some more words.

Do you know what those words are? I think the words are in the Sydney Morning Herald of 27 May. The words are direct quotes out of the Draper report. Who wrote the Draper report? A man. That was the first letter. All that stuff went to the minister. So the minister had in his ken a letter which quoted a man about secret women's business.

Mrs Kartinyeri is seminal to this debate because, as Cheryl Saunders said in her report, `She is a Ngarrindjeri elder whose knowledge about the women's business central to this report came from her grandmother and her Aunt Rosie, her mother's older sister.' The second invaluable point in this discussion is that three days later, in a letter dated the 12th that the minister had and still has, Doreen Kartinyeri said two things. She said, `I have recently become aware of the exact place to which this women's business refers.' Of course, it was Hindmarsh Island. She quoted three sources: her grandmother, long since dead; Laura Kartinyeri, currently known as Nanna Laura; and her Aunt Rosie, who died in 1981. So there was only one person alive who was the source of her information. Remember, she was quoted in the Saunders report as `the person who is central to this report'.

When Cheryl Saunders was asked in court in December last whether she had ever seen the letter of 12 May that the minister had, she answered that she was very surprised and had never seen it in her life. When you read the 56 pages of the Saunders report, Nanna Laura—as I will call her—is never mentioned.

So what happens? You cannot blame Cheryl Saunders unless she was told by somebody and did not do the work. Maybe you have to think about the evidence that Doreen Kartinyeri gave to Cheryl Saunders. But the one person who knew—and his office knew—after he read the report, albeit in a couple of days, which he received on 7 July, that the only person alive who could have verified the women's business was never asked.

So if you call that doing the job in detail and changing 140 years of anthropological history on the basis of it then that is the sort of detail that this minister went to. And he will not answer that question. He had two letters—one on 9 May and one on 12 May—which played a formative part in his appointing Cheryl Saunders, which he did on 23 May. He took notice, presumably, of the fact that a woman should do the thing, because the letters to him referred to women's business. When Cheryl Saunders' report came up, the one woman on earth who could have verified the truth or otherwise of this thing was not asked.

Unfortunately for this minister, a woman by the name of Dorothy Wilson was at that first meeting. She signed the first letter saying that she thought it was a sacred place and so forth. But on her way home that night she thought more about it and it worried her. She went to see Nanna Laura—Mrs Laura Kartinyeri, who was 88 years old last year and perfectly healthy at that time—and she asked her about the women. Remember, Nanna Laura is the most senior elder and known amongst the Ngarrindjeri people as that. Dorothy Wilson asked her whether it was true, and she was told that it was rubbish. The old lady had never heard of it.

Let me say a couple of things before I close. This issue has for a long time battled the consciences of these women who have now come out after a long time, because they realised it would cause disruption amongst the people in the Ngarrindjeri group. But they have at least put honour back into this operation. I have to say that, if this minister is not an accomplice in this operation, he is probably compliant in some sort of conspiracy. He has not answered the questions that he should have answered. I did not hear him answer one single question.

How is it that Saunders did not get near the anthropologists in the Adelaide museum? How is it that the only anthropologist was Deane Fergie, who was putting forward a representation for one of the protagonists? How is it that the minister made a recommendation for a declaration or made the declaration when only four women had ever heard of this? It could have been four; it may have been only one. How is it that last week the senior anthropologist at the Adelaide Museum came out and said that these things are blowing in from the desert?

How does the minister answer these questions? How is it that he did not notice that Cheryl Saunders was wrong in saying that Mr Justice Jacobs' recent report had said something about women's business when, of course, we all know that it did not? The fact of the matter is that he has not done the work, and this minister is going to lose out over this matter. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am embarrassed that we have had to hear the opposition members this afternoon, because it has been a pitiful attack. We need to understand that this is not about an attack on the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner). The interesting thing about this is that the fundamental element in all of this is misogynism. The common element is that this inquiry into the Hindmarsh Island bridge was carried out by a woman, who was disparaged by the opposition and disparaged by the member for Mayo (Mr Downer). The member for Mayo happened to say just a while ago in an aside across the table, `We shouldn't trust her because she might be married to a Labor member of parliament.' I don't know if she is or she isn't. You implied that she should not be trusted; that Cheryl Saunders, an independent person, should not be treated as an independent. We heard you.
—Who led the debate? A woman.

—Just sit down, Biggles. The consultant was a woman, Dr Deane Fergie. The matters of concern to Ngarrindjeri women are matters of women's knowledge. Three women have come under intense attack in a variety of guises, the most common being an attack from the opposition on either their independence—in the case of Professor Saunders and Dr Fergie—or their authenticity, in the case of Mrs Doreen Kartinyeri. This attack has come from three people—the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the member for Mayo and a number of his acolytes, including some who purport to be journalists, such as Piers Ackerman and other people writing in South Australian newspapers.

PARA.TAB: All of them have taken this approach of disparaging these women. They have not attacked their virtue. They have attacked these women as individuals, and they have tried to undermine the fact that these people have authenticity in their own right and have valid, recognisable knowledge which is recognised beyond the community. This is something which they will not accept. This is not about the minister. This is about the opposition's attacks on the independence of these women.

The fact that they are women concerns the opposition. The member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) is an unwitting dupe to the tactics of the opposition. She has been led down the garden path by the member for Barker, the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Mayo. These people are responsible for a despicable attack on people who are not present in this House and able to defend themselves. Yet continually they make these attacks. Since resigning McLachlan and his staff have been working overtime to discredit the Aboriginal claims on which the Federal Government's bridge veto was based. Last week he turned up five Aboriginal women who would say just that.

It has become a Federal election year issue and a vile one at that. And all this is so very far from where it began—with a bridge the Libs were determined to halt, a bridge one Labor premier had tried to halt, a bridge which a previous Labor premier had been as determined to deliver.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what this is about. It is about the member for Barker. It has nothing to do with the minister. It is the member for Barker, the member for Mayo, the Leader of the Opposition and their misogynism. That is what this is about. They have made it abundantly clear—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the member for Hindmarsh.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Jones: Indeed it is Doreen Kartinyeri seems to be the person who is a spokesperson?

Mr Howard: No. Well, I mean the most serious allegation in this whole thing is a suggestion that it was just completely concocted because there was no other way of stopping the construction of the bridge.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to withdraw it. The member for Barker said:

Cheryl Saunders is an interesting person, because she was the person chosen by the government to provide the independent advice, a person who has been attacked by the opposition. In the Weekend Australian on 27 May 1994, Justice Maurice O'Loughlin said about this person:

I reject the aspersions that have been cast on her and on the manner in which she performed her duties. There are areas in which I find myself unable to agree with her but they are matters of law; such disagreement does not reflect in any way on her integrity.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the chair.

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed works which were referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: the refurbishment of Australia House, London, United Kingdom.

SPEECH.PARA: The main elements of the proposed works are the implementation of a staged program of internal refurbishment providing tenancy conditions which meet the requirements of occupational health and safety with the replacement of outdated and obsolete equipment and providing office accommodation which meets current data and communications needs, and the refurbishment of areas surplus to high commission requirements for leasing to state governments and other agencies. PARA.TAB: The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works has made the following conclusions and recommendations in its report. TALK.START.PARA: —They don't want an inspection, do they?

—I think that is a broad hint. Until this legislation is amended to enable site inspections to be carried out overseas, the committee continues to reluctantly give approval for construction of projects which it has been unable to properly assess. The Public Works Committee Act 1969 be amended to remove the restriction on the Public Works Committee meeting outside of Australia and its external territories. There is a need to retain Australia House, London, as the focal point of Australia's representational activities in the United Kingdom. TALK.START.PARA: —The thesis I was putting to the House before question time was that as a consequence of the increase in taxation, not only in this Medicare Levy Bill but also in respect of the Keating government's increases in tax in previous budgets and this budget, many more families are going to be forced out of continuing private health insurance. That will put greater pressure on the public hospital sector and will increase costs. Therefore, the merry-go-round will continue with increasing demand on taxpayers' funds to sustain Medicare. PARA.TAB: The trajectory of this government in budgets up to the current budget has been to increase taxes in Australia, despite a promise not to increase taxes, by around $3 billion a year. I outlined those taxes before question time. In the budget before the House, taxes will increase by $2.4 billion in 1995-96, rising to $7.8 billion in 1998-99.

I remind honourable members—I notice that no government members are here other than the parliamentary secretary and another minister who is always attentive to my comments in the House, and I appreciate that—of some of the individual tax measures in this current budget, apart from the raising of the Medicare levy. The first is to increase company tax from 33 per cent to 36 per cent, which will take $3,970 million out of the private sector—money to invest in jobs and in the expansion of business and industry in Australia—over the next four years.

The Medicare levy will raise $1,010 million over four years, which will come out of the pockets of all Australians—PAYE taxpayers, wage earners, small businesses, families and farmers. That amount of money would be otherwise spent by those families in looking after themselves, being self-sufficient and, for many of them, continuing to pay private health insurance instead of being totally reliant on public health schemes, at a greater cost to the taxpayer.

The extension of sales tax on building materials will raise a total of $1,015 million over four years. Again, let us pause to reflect where that money is going to come from. Predominantly, it will come from young people who are trying to get their first home, who will now have to pay hundreds of dollars—according to one of the Labor members during question time, at least $1,500—per modest home for wholesales sales tax on building materials not presently covered by the wholesales sales tax legislation.

In respect of passenger motor vehicles used predominantly by families, by battlers in Australia, by small business, again I remind members on the other side, the sales tax proposals in this budget propose to raise $1,470 million over the next four years. The consequences of taking those vast sums of money out of families, out of the productive side of the economy, out of small business are clear—that can only result in less investment, less savings and more demands on the public purse.

It is obvious that that is the case when you consider the tax base that we already have and the fact that these people have had to suffer high interest rates during a massive recession and now regretfully a return to higher interest rates with three interest rate hikes over the past 12 months. If, as I fear, we follow the trend of the American economy, and with our huge debt and therefore the forces at work on the Australian economy, we are going to find, perhaps in the very short term, a slight dip in interest rates followed by a rise in interest rates as this government, if it is still in power—heaven forbid—grapples with the levers of managing this economy in the clumsy way that it has over the past 12 or 13 years.

I conclude by reminding the House of the sorts of statements that this government has made to the Australian people over many years. In the next few weeks as the election draws nearer and Australians have the opportunity to reflect and cast their vote on the sort of government they want for the future, not so much for themselves but for their children and grandchildren, I remind them of these sorts of statements and ask them to make a judgment on their own.
In the 1985 budget speech, the then Treasurer, our present Prime Minister (Mr Keating), promised:

SPEECH.PARA: I've outlined the Government's strategy for the new financial year. It's a strategy that builds upon our very significant success and puts further behind us the despair and economic failure of the former government.

The outcome—within months Australia was in the middle of the infamous banana republic current account crisis. In the following July, the Australian dollar collapsed to less than US60c, the lowest level on record. Since Labor came to power the Australian currency had lost almost 40 per cent of its value.

PARA.TAB: In his 1987 budget speech, the chronicle continues, the present Prime Minister promised:

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding the enormity of the trade difficulties we have faced, our economic strategy is now bearing fruit.
The outcome—within two years Australia was experiencing the largest current account blow-out on record.

PARA.TAB: In the 1988 budget speech, the present Prime Minister promised:

SPEECH.PARA: The nation is successfully emerging from its most severe economic crisis in a generation . . . this is the one that brings home the bacon. Our foreign debt burden has already stabilised and begun to fall.
The outcome—over the following year, net foreign debt rose by 22 per cent. Within two years Australia had entered the worst recession in 60 years.

PARA.TAB: On 24 August 1988, after his budget speech, the present Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are now well on our way back to prosperity.
The outcome—within two years Australia was in recession. In the 1989 budget speech, the present Prime Minister promised:
As a result of the Government's economic policies, Australia will emerge from the recent high level of spending without a recession and with its economic and social structure improving.
The outcome—within one year Australia was in the worst recession since the Great Depression of the 1930s. The present Prime Minister further promised:
Vital business investment will stay strong with growth in plant and equipment component expected to remain robust.
The outcome—in 1989-90, business investment fell by 0.2 per cent. The plant and equipment component fell much faster, by 4.2 per cent. The present Prime Minister also promised:

This year inflation will fall further, the current account deficit will markedly improve and employment will pick up . . . delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.
The outcome—in 1990-91, employment fell and Australia entered a recession which saw the unemployment rate rise to the highest level since the Great Depression.

PARA.TAB: In his 1992 speech on the budget, the present Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Keating government's economic strategy is to accelerate recovery from recession, and at the same time build a stronger Australia. It is a four year plan. It begins now with an immediate boost to spending and employment. It ends in 1995-96 with the budget back in surplus and dramatically reduced marginal income tax rates for most Australians.

The outcome—the government has admitted the budget will not be in surplus. It is selling off assets to fudge the balance of account. Within a year, Labor had broken its promise to deliver the second round of income tax cuts on 1 January 1996 and in fact introduced a range of new taxes, that I have outlined, in the last two budgets.

PARA.TAB: In the 1994 budget speech, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our forecast deficit for 1996-97 is now less than one per cent of GDP, and we expect the budget to be in surplus soon thereafter. In achieving this outcome, we have not increased general taxation.
The outcome—the 1994-95 budget papers estimated that total tax revenue was 21.9 per cent. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to thank the members for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans), Curtin (Mr Rocher), Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), Stirling (Mr Cameron), Cowan (Mr Richard Evans), McPherson (Mr Bradford) and Indi (Mr Chynoweth) for their contributions. —Don't you think that is relevant to the health of Australians?

I want to reply to some of the comments, especially in view of the fact that the shadow minister for health, the member for Chisholm, has indicated that the opposition will oppose the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. I regret the course of action taken by the opposition in relation to this. I particularly regret the fact that this action has been taken by the member for Chisholm, who has had a chequered history in this place but is one of the sensible and moderate members of the Liberal Party.

They buckle under, give way and do not stand up. Then they end up doing things which they later regret which goes on their record for a number of years. It is very unfortunate that the member for Chisholm has not been able to say, `It is a nonsense for us to oppose this very small increase in the Medicare levy.'
—And justified.

—And justified, as the Assistant Treasurer says. PARA.TAB: The member for Chisholm did not produce a single argument to support his position. What did we have from him? We had from him belated support for Medicare. After five election losses by the coalition parties in which Medicare was a central issue and in which health policy was a central issue, they finally recognise that the Australian people actually like Medicare, the Australian people support Medicare, the Australian people think Medicare is a very good policy. It is a lot for them to swallow, given their philosophical predilection, especially the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). It was very difficult for him to swallow. He said, `I support Medicare.' That was one of the hardest things he has ever had to do in politics. Given his new right philosophical basis—he does not believe in anything universal, especially universal health care—it was a very difficult thing for him to do. He is so desperate to win government that he said it. It was like his attempted reversal of his statements on multiculturalism and ethnic affairs. Never mind, we will discuss that at another time.

The Australian people know that any embracing of Medicare by the opposition is very reluctant and is not based on any philosophical commitment to the principles of Medicare. The first opportunity members of the opposition get, whatever excuse they get—if they were to get into government—they would run away from the universal nature of Medicare. Remember when Malcolm Fraser went to the people in 1975. He said, `We will retain Medibank.' Within months of getting into office, Medibank was out the window—the universal health system was out the window. We had to bring it back in 1983 in a new form, to sustain the health system.

For the shadow minister to talk in here about the virtues of a health system and to say that the minister is mistaken in her policies because of the issues of private health insurance, which do not concern this bill, is amazing. Let me address those questions at this level. We will listen to the shadow minister in some serious way, and the Australian people will listen to the shadow minister and the opposition in some serious way, when they come up with some proposal. Every time this idea of a policy free zone is raised, the opposition leader chuckles and thinks it is a big joke. If you think it is a big joke not to have a policy on this private health area—and they have none; they have ditched the previous one; God knows what it is now—and then to get up and say that there are some problems in private health insurance which the minister has not dealt with is a joke. The minister has pushed through this chamber and through the dreaded Senate a bill to put into place a new system to deal with the issues concerning private health insurance. Let us not hear any more nonsense from the shadow minister about this.

I come back to this fundamental point: the moderates in the Liberal Party had better start standing up, because there will not be any left. Mr Deputy Speaker Rocher, you are one of those moderates. What has happened to you? You have been knocked off for preselection. What about the other moderate who is here now, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly)? He has been knocked off for preselection. The way things are going, the moderates in the Liberal Party will be able to meet in a telephone booth. That is how bad things are in the Liberal Party. They have knocked off all the moderate members, and then tonight we are to hear a speech about how they are going to move the party to the centre ground. All these hard, New Right people have suddenly discovered the centre ground. If you believe that, you will believe anything. Whenever they have had an opportunity to preselect members that really believed in some moderation and in some traditional small `l' liberal principles, what have they done? They have knocked them off at preselection.
I say to the member for Chisholm—unfortunately, he is not here, but he has tendered his apologies; he wanted to be here—he had better be careful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Macphee and Chaney were moderates.

—The Hon. Ian Macphee was one of the most distinguished members of this House. The Hon. Fred Chaney was one of the moderates. In the meantime, we are asked to believe they are going to bring in some kind of policy that makes sense in the area of health and human services. We will wait and see.

PARA.TAB: Let us turn to the comments of the honourable member for Curtin, who is in the chair at the moment. He raised the question about the limit to the levy and said that it would be logical for the government to go on increasing the levy until it covered the whole cost of health services. With respect, those comments are based on a misunderstanding. At no time has the government ever stated that the intention of the Medicare levy was to cover all the health costs. From the beginning we recognised that the Medicare levy was only a contribution towards health costs. It continues to be so. Therefore, the levy is only making part of that contribution towards the fundamental cost. Unlike the opposition, we understand that additional measures are required in order to raise sufficient funds for health and human services—fundamental issues in social justice, health and human services.

As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said yesterday, the Leader of the Opposition does not seem to understand what the social wage is about. Health and human services are the fundamental elements of the social wage. It is very interesting that in a 20-minute speech attacking the Prime Minister yesterday the Leader of the Opposition mentioned the words `social wage' a number of times, but he did not explain a single thing about it—not what it means and what it is all about. He was very happy to use the word `battlers'. When it comes to serious policy and to discussing the issues of social justice and the social wage—the human services component of the social wage and the health component of the social wage—what does the Leader of the Opposition do? He does not have a clue. He did not talk about it. He left it to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), to try to say something about it. For 15 or 20 minutes the Leader of the Opposition attacked the Prime Minister personally about this issue, but he did not in any way say what it really means or give his understanding of it. If you go to the record and look for the two words `social justice' under the words `John Howard' you cannot find anything. He never talks about that, unlike the member for Bradfield and several others who have talked about it; unlike the member for Curtin who has talked about some of these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us the name of your book.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—It is all right to mention it as proceedings are not being broadcast.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, Mr Deputy Speaker, the proceedings are not being broadcast. Let me talk about the comments of the member for Stirling. He raised no real issues in relation to this matter. I am not sure whether he or another member of the opposition who came afterwards attempted to attack the minister personally. I considered that an outrage. He tried to attack the minister personally by somehow implying that the minister had used her influence to have an operational procedure done without waiting very long.

PARA.TAB: Let me make these points about this matter: firstly, it is true that the minister underwent a procedure. She did so while she was Premier of Western Australia. It was done in a private hospital, not in a public hospital. She certainly did not push her way through to the top of the queue. She paid for the operation herself. She chose this course of action in order to avoid putting any additional burden on the public health system. This is the position which a number of Australians have taken. For whatever reason, they have chosen not to have private health insurance but to pay the full cost in private hospitals of operations and the like. Whichever member raised this issue—the member for Stirling or another member—it was disgraceful to raise the issue in the context of this debate. The minister acted in a totally honourable fashion. The government is not interested in these personal attacks of the kind that we are getting from the opposition. We are interested in getting on with governing this country. I know you all think that at the first sign of our going up in the polls we will call an election, but that is not the issue at all. Our main concern is to govern this country well.

TALK.START.PARA: —We want good governance of Australia.

—Good governance, as the honourable member says. In the area of human services and health, as in a number of other social areas, we have developed volumes of policy. We have developed a large range of programs, vast networks of administration that are delivering the policies and even in certain cases forcing conservative, reactionary state liberal coalition governments into social policy. In some cases we have had to drag them. A good example of that is the fact that we have had to drag the Kennett government into the child-care system, after 2 1/2 years, and we also tried to drag the Fahey government into the scheme. It took the defeat of that government before New South Wales would become involved in the program. This is the attitude towards social programs which the conservatives have had and will always have.

PARA.TAB: In the area of health, we should have been developing a bipartisan approach. Instead, we have had from the shadow minister determination to oppose this measure. I regret that. It is a sorry indication that the conservatives, the New Right in the opposition, are increasingly getting the upper hand. They are not interested in responsible decision making; they simply want to block a number of measures in the budget with the idea of using that as an electoral tool. They will not escape this proposal, because the Australian people in general accept the fact that Medicare is a positive system and that this increase is a small, necessary increase which will assist in the overall operation of the health system—including the new programs which were announced in the budget, especially a program to assist Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and other programs in a range of areas, including programs directed towards people from non-English speaking backgrounds and people with particular problems. All these programs will be very positive and I believe that increasing the Medicare levy by this small amount, while not paying for all these programs, will help to pay for some.

This legislation is a very responsible measure and should be totally supported by any party which claims that it would have any responsibility in government. I bitterly regret the fact that the opposition is opposing it, and totally reject the argument of those opposite.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) MODIFICATION (EXCISE) BILL 1995Cognate Bills:SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) MODIFICATION (CUSTOMS) BILL 1995SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) MODIFICATION (GENERAL) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 9 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The bills will modify the sales tax law to give effect to certain announcements in the 1995-96 budget.

PARA.TAB: The bills will increase the rate of sales tax applying to non-luxury passenger motor vehicles from 16 per cent to 21 per cent. The rate of sales tax applying to the portion of the value of luxury passenger motor vehicles below the luxury threshold will also be increased in line with the rate for non-luxury passenger motor vehicles. These changes will take effect from budget night.

The sales tax applying to non-luxury passenger motor vehicles was reduced from the general rate as an anti-cyclical measure in the 1992 One Nation statement. Strong growth in the economy has removed any need for the concessional rate.
The gain to revenue of these measures is likely to be $18 million for 1994-95, $330 million for 1995-96, $355 million for 1996-97, $380 million for 1997-98 and $405 million for 1998-99.

The bills make clear that safes, musical instruments including pianos and other keyboards, and ornaments in the nature of bric-a-brac are not entitled to the concessional rate of sales tax applicable to household furniture. These changes will take effect from budget night.

The modifications are necessary following recent disputes where taxpayers have claimed that these goods, which have long been considered taxable at the general rate, should be treated as furniture and, therefore, subject to the concessional rate of 11 per cent. The government considers it necessary to legislate to ensure that these goods continue to be taxed at the general rate. These modifications will prevent the potential for revenue leakage rather than directly increasing revenue.

The sales tax law provides an exemption from sales tax for aircraft. A recent court decision has resulted in this exemption being extended to model aircraft capable of flight. This is at odds with the longstanding policy on the treatment of model aircraft. The bills will ensure that all model aircraft are again taxed at the general rate of sales tax, along with other toys. This modification will take effect from budget night. It has not been possible to quantify the gain to the revenue for this measure.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Scaffolding components, wall and floor safes, shelving systems

PARA.TAB: The bills will reverse the effect of recent court decisions, which have expanded the scope of sales tax exemptions for building materials beyond what was originally intended, with regard to scaffolding components, wall and floor safes and shelving systems. That is, the bills will ensure that these goods, which have long been accepted as being subject to sales tax, will not be eligible for sales tax exemptions. These changes will take effect from budget night. These modifications will prevent the potential for revenue leakage rather than directly increasing revenue.

The bills will make certain categories of currently exempt building materials taxable at the concessional rate, which will be 12 per cent when the modification comes into effect on 1 July 1995. This measure will apply the 12 per cent rate to a wide range of building materials used in the completion of buildings, including goods such as wall and floor tiles, plaster, taps and nozzles, timber floor coverings, paints, putties, fillers, wallpaper, builders hardware and some items of prefabricated joinery.
The gain to the revenue of the measures is likely to be $215 million for 1995-96, $245 million for 1996-97, $265 million for 1997-98 and $290 million for 1998-99.

Certain goods made from recycled paper are exempt from sales tax provided the goods are made entirely from recycled paper. The government considers that this sales tax exemption is inefficient and likely to impede efficient industry development. The bills, therefore, remove the sales tax exemption for goods made from recycled paper. This modification will take effect from l November 1995.

The gain to revenue of these measures is likely to be $7 million for 1995-96, $13 million for 1996-97, $14 million for 1997-98 and $15 million for 1998-99. Full details of the measures are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable members. I commend the bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Modification (Excise) Bill 1995 and cognate bills, together with the previous bill relating to the increase in the Medicare levy and subsequent bills relating to taxation which the government will deal with in this place this week, are in effect the mechanism by which this government commits electoral fraud on the people of Australia. In this legislation we have an increase in sales tax on two items about which the government had intimated and indicated there would be no such increase; namely, an increase in tax on cars and also an increase in tax on building products.

PARA.TAB: As the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) pointed out, we find in these bills an increase in sales tax in a number of areas: an increase in sales tax payable on passenger motor vehicles to the general rate of 21 per cent, up from 16 per cent; a modification of the sales tax law to remove the exemption for a range of building materials which will become taxable now at the rate of 12 per cent; and a series of other tax increases or modifications to make it clear that tax applies to free standing safes, musical instruments, ornaments, model aircraft, scaffolding components, wall and floor safes, racking and shelving systems; and last, but not least, a modification in sales tax law to remove the sales tax exemption for certain 100 per cent recycled paper products.

I indicate to the House that the coalition will vote against, will oppose, those increases in sales tax on building products and on cars. We will be voting against these items because, in our opinion, the implementation of these proposals represents an electoral fraud on the people of Australia.

I am reminded in this debate of a conversation that I had with my daughter recently. She said to me in her childhood way, `What does it mean when someone says to you, Dad, "A man is as good as his word"?' I said, `Well, it's about being honest. "A man is as good as his word" means he'll keep his word and he'll be honest.' I said by way of example, `If I said to you, "I'll give you $5 extra pocket money if you'll help clean up your room and help clean up around the place," but when it came time to pay it to you the next week I said, "No, you've done all the work but I'm not going to pay it. I'm going to take it back," would that be honest?'

She said, `No, of course not.' I said, `If I gave you a doll and then I said later, "Listen, I'm taking it back. I gave it to you but it is not really yours to keep. You've had it for a day. I said you could have it but now I am going to take it back," would that be honest?' She said, `No, of course not, Dad.' So I said, `Well, that is what it means when we say, "A man is as good as his word." When something is said in relation to a certain proposal or proposition, it means that that word will be kept.' What we can say in relation to this legislation is that a man is as good as his word—but we see that the word is simply not being kept.

Let me deal with some of the actual proposals in the legislation; first of all, the increase in sales tax on cars. Let us go back to the famous One Nation statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 26 February 1992. In the ministerial statement that the Prime Minister stood at this dispatch box here and delivered to this place and to the people of Australia, he had this to say about motor vehicles:
From tomorrow the sales tax on new cars currently subject to the 20 per cent rate will be permanently—

SPEECH.PARA: permanently—
lowered to 15 per cent—a saving on a new Commodore or Falcon of around $800.

PARA.TAB: With cheaper cars we will drive newer cars, which is good for the environment, good for road safety, and good for one of our most important industries.

SPEECH.PARA: He said there would be a permanent lowering of sales tax on motor vehicles from 20 to 15 per cent. What does this piece of legislation propose? It proposes that we increase the sales tax on motor vehicles from 16 to 21 per cent. When we ask about the impact of this, we do not have to go any further than what the Prime Minister himself said in February 1992:
. . . a saving on a new Commodore or Falcon of around $800.

So the impact on ordinary purchasers of motor vehicles of this particular measure, if the prices are about the same as they were in 1992, is an increased cost of some $800 on a new Falcon or a new Holden.

PARA.TAB: This is just part of the increasing cost of transport under this government. We have seen fuel excise rise from some 6c to 34c per litre. A survey by the Royal Automobile Club of Victoria showed that the cost of running a car over the last year has gone up for a private vehicle by some $13 and for a commercial vehicle by some $48. This is a measure which will have an immediate impact once it is introduced—if it is not defeated elsewhere—on ordinary purchasers of cars. My local dealer in Holden Commodores in Doncaster has already said that he has detected a marked shift in the attitude of buyers in relation to this particular measure.

In a country that has an aged vehicle fleet—a country whose vehicle fleet is much older than those in most of the developed world—this measure will make it more difficult for people to buy cars. What about the environmental concerns? If we have already got an ageing fleet and this proposal makes it more difficult to buy cars, then we can expect that fewer people will buy cars, which will add to the environmental problem.

In answer to a question about this in parliament in the last week, the Prime Minister said that no-one in the motor industry should be surprised by this. No-one would be surprised because it is a complete reversal of a policy from the Prime Minister, and that is what everyone—those in the motor industry and elsewhere—has come to expect; that when he says one thing he will actually turn around and do another. The word `permanent' has no realistic meaning at all in the language of the Prime Minister of this country. The word `permanent' becomes meaningless; it becomes a word that means temporary. The moral of this story, if we go back to taking a man at his word, is that the word of the Prime Minister of Australia that something is permanent means that it is temporary. So much for the word of the Prime Minister.

The next proposal deals with the increase in sales tax on building materials. Prior to the 1993 election we were told over and over again in this place and on every media outlet, on radio and television stations around the nation, that we did not need an increase in sales tax. The Prime Minister and members of the government campaigned the length and breadth of this nation saying, `We don't need increases in sales tax and in particular we don't need a goods and services tax.'

Remember the advertisements that were played on television stations night after night of a cash register with 15 per cent jingling up? The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) remembers them very well. The whole purport of those advertisements was, `We're not going to have a GST. We're not going to have a 15 per cent increase in GST. We're not going to have in any way an increase in sales tax.' The one clear, unambiguous message that came from the government, from the Prime Minister, from the Treasurer (Mr Willis), from the frontbench and from the backbench was that there would be no increase in sales tax.

In November 1992, the Prime Minister said clearly, in words which one could hardly put a different meaning on, `What I am promising is not to put up tax.' If you look at Hansard transcripts, you will see that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) on 5 May rejected categorically any tax increases on the housing industry; as did the then Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, on 30 April 1992. `No sales tax on the building industry,' said the Deputy Prime Minister and the then Treasurer, `We're not going to do that. We promise the opposite, just like the Prime Minister said.'

What do we make of the word of the Prime Minister? Can we take the man at his word? In this legislation a whole raft of items commonly used in the building industry are now going to be subject to a 12 per cent sales tax. Let us just look at what those things are. Plaster, used in raw materials in construction and repair, and the ingredients for plaster mixes will all be subject to a 12 per cent sales tax.

Builders' hardware such as nails, rivets, washers, screws, bolts and nuts will all be subject to a 12 per cent sales tax. Every time a builder hammers a nail into a piece of wood—and how many nails go into building an extension to a house, let alone building a new house?—there will be a 12 per cent tax on that nail as well as on every bolt, nut and screw that goes into that building. At the present time some floor coverings are subject to tax, but all wall and floor tiles will now be subject to a 12 per cent tax.

So far we have got the plaster going into raw materials in construction and repair, the nails, bolts, screws and nuts that hold together all the wood that goes into the building of a house and the wall and floor tiles that make up the construction of a house or a renovation going to be taxed. In addition to that, timber floor coverings and parquet blocks will also be subject to a 12 per cent sales tax.

If that is not enough, the list goes on: paints, putties and wallpaper will be subject to a 12 per cent sales tax. So, if people are going to paint the bathroom or put up some wallpaper in the spare room, as of 1 July 1995 the Prime Minister will rip off from them another 12 per cent in sales tax. Not only that; taps, nozzles, tap handles or shower heads installed in houses will be subject to a 12 per cent sales tax.

When cyclical variations affect the underlying rate of the current account deficit as they did in 1982, 1986, 1990 and 1995 and when the proportion of GDP approaches six per cent, for sensible reasons, growth has slowed. There are only two answers to that constraint on Australia's long-term economic growth. The first is to make the economy more competitive. This legislation is a very important part of the government's savings strategy that is designed to bring the federal budget into surplus. These sales tax measures will add to public savings.
