PARA.TAB: We can only close the gap between national savings and national investment by lifting the savings stock in Australia. We always hear from the opposition that public savings are very important to achieve that. Moving the federal budget from a deficit in 1994-95 to a healthy surplus in 1995-96 is the biggest contribution to public savings that has been seen in the fiscal policy area for a long while. You have to go back to the mid-1980s to see such an important contribution to public savings.

This is a genuine nation building task to allow the Australian economy to break free of any growth restraint on the external account. It can only happen by increasing national savings which by definition means lowing the share of consumption. There is one thing that should be tattooed onto the foreheads of those opposite—this would allow the press gallery to read it every day when those opposite go to their press conferences—and that is that GDP is equal to national savings plus national consumption. Any party that comes into this place with a savings strategy needs to be aware that improved savings as a proportion of GDP mean a lower share for consumption.

That is an undeniable and unavoidable economic rule. It demonstrates the point that in terms of a credible savings strategy there is no quick fix and there is no magic pudding. Savings can only be achieved as a proportion of GDP at the expense of consumption. These sales tax measures before the House are a very important improvement in public savings that also acknowledge a decline in private rates of consumption. They add significantly to Australia's economic strategy. Part of the government's savings strategy on the one hand is to move into a structural surplus in the budget after this, having had this budget in technical surplus, and on the other hand to introduce a superannuation savings strategy that the opposition could only dream about when it was last in government.

The first measure of the legislation is to increase the sales tax payable on passenger motor vehicles to the general rate of 21 per cent—that is, to move it from 16.5 per cent back to 21 per cent where it was prior to One Nation. This acknowledges another economic truth that the opposition should accept—that is, the One Nation statement was designed for counter-cyclical reasons. It was designed to lift Australia out of a period of low consumption and low aggregate demand and get the economy growing again, which it did so magnificently. Having achieved the counter-cyclical purpose of One Nation, and with the economy now growing so strongly, it is perfectly legitimate for this government to change policy three years after One Nation and bring the passenger motor vehicles back to the general sales tax rate.

How has the car industry changed in those three years? Three years ago, at the time of One Nation, the car industry was suffering from a lack of consumption, a lack of aggregate demand, in the Australian economy. But now, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) pointed out last week in question time, we have waiting times of six months for some Australian cars. If you decide to purchase an Australian produced car in 1995, there is up to a six-month wait for some models to be delivered. That is how strong the demand and the consumption have become in 1995.

The very reason why the sales tax was reduced three years ago has disappeared totally because industry changes. Market conditions are constantly evolving, and it is only sensible that a government would react to those changes. You are a dumb lot if you make no response in policy to changed circumstances. The first principle of good government is change with the times.

If aggregate demand and consumption are running away too strongly, if they are spilling over into problems on the external account, the nation needs to address its lack of savings. It can do so by re-establishing the sales tax rate for passenger motor vehicles. It is a very sensible and simple proposition which should be embraced by the opposition and not be the subject of scare campaigns, cheap election populism, or cheap point scoring exercises.

So too is the application of sales tax to a number of building materials sensible. The revenue gain estimated in 1995-96 is $215 million. At various times, both sides of the House have conceded that an important goal for the national savings strategy is to narrow the distortions in the taxation treatment of alternative forms of saving. It is a very simple proposition. This was reflected most clearly in the FitzGerald report on national savings which was at the time heralded by the then shadow Treasurer, the member for Mayo (Mr Downer), as a landmark report, something the government should act on.

So here is the government in the 1995-96 budget trying to narrow the distortion by lifting the effective tax rate on owner-occupied housing, but only by a modest amount. Still it is moving in the right direction. What is so outstanding about the government's saving strategy is that it is moving in the right direction. A willingness to increase national savings, particularly public savings, and just take the top off private consumption at the very peak of the economic cycle is good economic policy. It is outstanding economic policy.

The real task in Australia in terms of the housing sector is to knock the top off conspicuous housing consumption. Every dollar in this country that goes into conspicuous housing consumption is a dollar that is not going into bank savings, share equities or employee superannuation contributions, where it could be used to finance Australia's aggressive rate of investment.

My experience with this goes back to my days in local government when one of the business people in the city of Liverpool made a windfall gain on a property development exercise. I asked that business person, `What will you do with your windfall gain? Will you put it into value added investment, a bit of manufacturing, a bit of share investment? Conspicuous housing consumption at that luxury level of the market, when it is dragging on the pool of savings and adding to consumption in such an economically useless fashion, is against the national interest. This government recognises that fact, as did the opposition years ago. At the time of Fightback and John Hewson's leadership of the Liberal Party, he set this as a legitimate goal for public policy—that is, to narrow the distortions in the effective taxation treatment of alternative forms of savings.

In the national and public interest, this parliament should not be afraid of taxation measures which affect the housing sector, particularly measures as modest as this 12 per cent rate on a narrow band of building materials. To listen to the opposition, you would think that the roof was going to fall in, literally. The truth is that this is for the average home buyer an entirely affordable sales tax regime.

It is important to move at that top end of the housing market and knock the top off the conspicuous housing consumption so admired by members opposite. For the national economic interest, it is of very little value. It is in fact a drain on the national savings pool.

My conclusion on these measures, and I wish it was reflected in the contributions of opposition members, is that there is no quick fix, no magic pudding, no easy way in which to improve this nation's savings pool because as a proportion of GDP it means improving savings at the expense of the consumption share. The Australian people understand that. Over the 12 years of the internationalisation of the Australian economy, Australians have become more sophisticated in understanding the economic debate. They are looking out for the carpetbaggers, the election populists and the opportunists and they will finger them at the first available opportunity. These bills are a continuation of Labor's drive to introduce a consumption tax by surreptitious means. As I mentioned earlier, the amount of indirect sales tax collected by the government will increase by 22.3 per cent this year. It is also interesting to look at Labor's record since 1982-83. Over Labor's long 12 years in office, it has increased sales tax revenue by a whopping 305.7 per cent. This is almost double the increase in total revenue over the same period, and this has happened when inflation has totalled about 68.4 per cent.

The sales tax increases as outlined in the budget do nothing more than magnify Labor's tax lies and continue the trend of Labor's earlier budgets. The measures outlined in the budget include an increase in sales tax payable on passenger motor vehicles from 16 per cent to the general rate, which is currently 21 per cent; modification of the sales tax law to make it clear that freestanding safes, musical instruments and ornaments are not entitled to the concession afforded to furniture; modification of the sales tax law to ensure that sales tax is paid on model aircraft at the general rate; modification of the sales tax law to ensure that sales tax is paid on scaffolding components, wall and floor safes and racking and shelving systems; amendments to the sales tax law to remove exemption from a range of building materials, which will become taxable at the rate of 12 per cent; and, finally, modification of the sales tax law to remove the sales tax exemption for certain 100 per cent recycled paper products.

The inclusion of some building products in the sales tax regime effectively hails the introduction of a building industry goods and services tax. What goods are included? They are screws, nails, paint, putty, adhesives, wallpaper, ceramic and glass floor and wall tiles, taps, nozzles, handles and joinery, such as prefabricated cupboards and office partitioning. This increased application of sales tax will increase the price of an average new home by an estimated $1,000 to $2,000. It will also increase the price of renovations and extensions to existing houses.

This is no way to treat struggling first home buyers. Labor has simply no regard for mainstream Australia, and this sales tax hike is just one more example of that. Labor has the hide to do this, just as the building industry is in a sharp decline. The government has shown impeccable timing by doing the wrong thing at the wrong time. If it wants to dampen demand, it is already damp. It is drowning.

I note that the budget papers take note of those building materials which will not be subject to the sales tax, but what is interesting is the explanation of why some building goods are to be taxed and others are not. The papers state:

SPEECH.PARA: This measure will address some existing disparities in the WAST treatment of goods; for example, fittings such as sinks, toilets, baths and towel rails are currently taxed at the rate of 11 percent rate but associated taps, nozzles and shower heads have been exempt.

The futility of this change is mind-boggling. Has the government not yet realised that to eliminate one disparity in the sales tax rules creates another one elsewhere? If nails and screws are hit with the sales tax, why not the timber into which the nails are to be hammered? The plaster is to be taxed but not the wood it is attached to. Where is the sense in it? This is only one of the many problems with the existing sales tax system. The system is in serious need of major overhaul. The ad hoc changes like those currently before us do no more than add to the complexity of the law and do nothing to rectify the inherent problems in the sales tax system.

PARA.TAB: When sales tax was first introduced by the Scullin Labor government on 1 August 1930, it was levied at the rate of 2.5 per cent, it was broad based and it was designed to be imposed at the wholesale level. Few goods were then exempt, but the following were: goods exported; goods sold by a dispensing chemist; medicine sold by a friendly society; retail goods sold by a manufacturer that were made to meet an individual customer order; small manufactures; primary products; and a limited list of other exempt goods. Within 12 months the rate was increased to six per cent. It was only during the Second World War that differentiated rates of sales tax were introduced.

This sales tax system, with much tinkering occurring over the rates of tax and exempt goods, remained largely unchanged until 1992. It was in that year that the government announced it had accepted a series of measures to simplify and improve the sales tax system.

In this task, of course, Labor has failed dismally. This simplification effort was later renamed `streamlining'. Streamlining, God help us! This so-called streamlining does nothing to relieve the burden of the sales tax system on business. Business is affected by the compliance costs of meeting all obligations under the law, and sales tax continues to be built into the cost of business inputs. So-called streamlining has, by all accounts, made the operation of the sales tax system by the Australian Taxation Office much smoother but has done nothing—absolutely nothing—to improve the lot of complying taxpayers.

Apparently, there are 1,109 taxpayer entities contributing 75.4 per cent of total sales tax revenue, for which the cost of complying with the law is relatively cheap. However, there are 75,000 small to medium sized businesses which have to pay sales tax and which face much higher compliance costs. According to the Australian Tax Research Foundation, entities paying over $1 million sales tax per annum—that is just over 1,000 companies—incurred a compliance cost of less than 0.4 per cent of the tax paid or collected and remitted. However, those with annual sales tax liabilities of $50,000 or less, 85 per cent of all entities paying sales tax, incurred a compliance cost of nearly 25 per cent on the tax collected and remitted.
These findings are supported by Mr Jeff Pope in a research paper published in August 1994. Mr Pope stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The estimated total compliance costs of WST in 1990/91 are $179 million, or 1.9 percent of the WST revenue of $9,365 million.
Internal costs account for 95 percent and external costs (professional fees) account for 5 percent.
Compliance costs as a percentage of tax paid are regressive, falling from 24 percent to 0.13 percent.

The smallest taxpayers remit an average of four dollars of tax for every dollar spent on compliance costs, compared with WST remittance of $799 per dollar of compliance costs for the largest taxpayers.
That is a ridiculous situation—and it is regressive, as Mr Pope has pointed out. The system simply requires simplification—not more tinkering.

PARA.TAB: The other point I raise, which negatively impacts on business, is that sales tax continues to be built into the cost of business inputs. This is because in many cases wholesale sales tax is not paid directly but indirectly through the higher prices charged by suppliers who themselves must pay sales tax. The available system of exemptions has done little to reduce the amount of sales tax cascading throughout the production process of too many firms throughout our economy.

There is also a whole range of other indirect taxes, such as fuel excise and payroll tax, which business must pay for either directly or indirectly through the higher costs passed on by their suppliers. These taxes are built into the price of a whole range of goods and services that are purchased in the course of conducting business activities.

The general criticisms of the sales tax system are many. But the government's ad hoc approach will not solve the problems. The reality is that this government merely ignores the problems in the sales tax system. It ignores the distortion of production and consumption decisions that come about because some goods are hit by sales tax while other goods are not. It ignores the further distortions that result from having a multiple indirect tax rate structure which includes very high rates of tax on some goods.

The new measures fail to address the vast array of anomalies that have emerged under the wholesale sales tax, both in the sales tax treatment of certain goods and in the range of exemptions made available to some users of these goods but not to others. There is no recognition of the cascading effect of sales tax, and other indirect taxes for that matter, through the production process. Sales tax will continue to fall heavily on intermediate business inputs, investment goods and exports in addition to the burden placed on consumers. The wholesales sales tax system thus serves to undermine the productive and export potential of Australian businesses.

Anomalies in the sales tax system are widespread and, without doubt, beyond resolution by this government. Wedding rings are exempt from sales tax, yet engagement rings are taxed at 31 per cent. Cordial is taxed at 11 per cent, but soft drinks are taxed at 21 per cent. Some household wares are taxed at 11 per cent, but cleaning and other products are taxed at 21 per cent. Biscuits and snack products are taxed—they are also relatively more often consumed by lower income people—yet caviar, crayfish, expensive meats and exotic fruits, which are more likely to be purchased by higher income groups, are not taxed. On a slightly different tack, why should a sign painted on a wall not be subject to sales tax while a sign painted on a board and then attached to the wall is? Why do these anomalies remain in the sales tax system? David Vos of Coopers and Lybrand has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is understood the Labor Party and the Democrats believe in the selective taxing of different goods based on their relative nature.
However, the greater number of classifications, the greater the complexity.

Sales tax is presently complex because governments over the years have moved the rate of sales tax on particular goods up or down to appease some whim or to settle some perceived anomaly or inconsistency.
Solve one anomaly, and the government creates another.

What is the best way of fixing the problem? The simplest way to solve the tax problem would be to abolish sales tax and introduce a consumption tax along the lines of a value added tax or a goods and services tax. This method would even fix the issue of tax payable on the sign that I mentioned earlier. However, the people of Australia rejected that at the last poll. It is off the agenda, and it will not return. The only other viable solution, therefore, is to scrap the existing sales tax system and rebuild it from scratch with simplicity being the No. 1 priority.

PARA.TAB: There is a need to have only one sales tax rate apply across the board so that sales tax applies as widely as possible and exemptions are kept to a minimum. The only exemptions that should be built into the sales tax system are those for business inputs and exports. To have sales tax and excises built into the price of exports is simply a disgrace. It handicaps Australian exporters trying to operate in an extremely competitive international market.

In conclusion, sales tax needs a major overhaul. The government's so-called streamlining is inadequate. Labor must make the necessary changes to the sales tax system to reduce the cost of compliance and get off the backs of Australian businesses—in particular, our exporters. Unfortunately, Labor has no policy direction with the present Prime Minister at the helm. Only the election of a coalition government will bring about the necessary reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sales tax legislation now before the House gives effect to certain revenue raising measures announced in the 1995 budget. In that budget, the government announced a combination of cost-cutting measures and revenue raising measures that have brought the federal budget into surplus well ahead of schedule.

PARA.TAB: The primary aim of this strategy has been to reduce, as much as the government can, those market pressures on interest rates. Recent interest rate trends in the marketplace indicate that the government's strategy has been largely successful. Reports in today's national media indicate that short-term rates have fallen below the Reserve Bank official rate of 7.5 per cent and that long-term rates were slashed by 0.4 of a percentage point in response to the budget.

As far as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the coalition are concerned, this good news is the stuff nightmares are made of. The opposition's position has always been to blame the government when there are interest rate rises and congratulate everybody else when interest rates fall. These falls are good news for Australian households and businesses throughout the Geelong region, and especially for those home buyers who are now reaping the benefits of a price cutting war on fixed home loan rates in the marketplace.

As I said before, the primary aim of the budget was to reduce, as best the government could, the pressures on interest rates and we have been spectacularly successful in that respect. The sales tax legislation before the House relates primarily to the following goods: recycled paper, building materials, model aircraft, passenger motor vehicles, scaffolding, racking and shelving and floor safes.

It is the proposed increase in the sales tax on motor vehicles that I would like to comment a bit more on in this debate. While I understand and appreciate the overall strategy of the government of bringing the budget into surplus this year and reducing that pressure on interest rates, the sales tax increase has meant that several of my constituents who had placed their orders for vehicles as far back as December 1994 and January and February 1995 must now deal with a set of economic and commercial circumstances they did not anticipate when they placed their orders.

I have given those constituents an undertaking that I would raise this matter in debate in the House and I am doing so here tonight. In a sense, they have been caught in a commercial crossfire. It is their particular circumstance which prompted me to request the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to examine any possibility at all of exempting these constituents who had longstanding orders for motor vehicles from the sales tax increase.

I will expand on their circumstance. As I mentioned earlier, many placed orders especially with Ford dealers to purchase Ford cars as far back as December 1994 and February 1995. Some of those people were Ford employees who, because they receive some concessions on purchases of company vehicles, are continually rescheduled to the bottom of the dealer's customer list when the general demand is strong and vehicles are in short supply. What we have seen in the marketplace in recent times is a strong demand for Ford cars and a difficulty on the part of the company in supplying that demand.

I am reliably informed that Ford was unable to achieve more than 10 production days in April 1995 due to industrial action that occurred outside of the company, with the BTR Nylex dispute, and some internal industrial disputation Ford itself faced. These factors, coupled with the public holidays that occurred in April, simply meant that the company did not get any more than 10 production days, which set its production schedules back enormously and has led to this pent-up demand in the marketplace. These factors exacerbated Ford's supply problem and, coupled with the strong demand for its vehicles, has brought about a vehicle delivery situation which has stretched to months.

One would have thought that Ford customers would have been allowed to renegotiate their purchase contracts with the dealers, given these extraordinary circumstances which have occurred beyond their control. But, unfortunately, that is not the case. The fine print in the dealers' contracts makes the customer liable for increases brought about by factors such as the ones we are debating in this House tonight. The unfortunate thing about it is that many of those customers were not made aware by the dealers of the fine print in those contracts and are now liable for any increases. Dealers, of course, have refused to absorb even part of any increase that has occurred.

Many of my constituents have been caught in that commercial crossfire. We have seen strong demand for the Ford product and difficulty in supply and delivery by that company which has been quite beyond the customers' control. They have had to deal with the fine print in the dealers' contracts, which does not enable them to get any redress from the dealers, and they have had to contend with the increases in the sales tax that have been brought down in the budget.

As I have stated, I wrote to the Treasurer outlining the particular circumstances many of my constituents found themselves in, and I did request him to explore the issue of bona fide exemptions. The Treasurer has advised me that such exemptions are not possible because of the precedents that they set, and that the government has followed on this occasion the practice of previous Liberal governments and previous Labor governments in scheduling any sales tax increases from budget night.

I understand, also, that such exemptions would be extremely complex to administer, given the point at which the tax is levied and given the arrangements that dealers make with their wholesalers, or their wholesaling arm, to delay to the last possible moment the point at which the consumer actually pays the money over to the retailer.

The Treasurer holds the view that the financial integrity of the budget has to be maintained on this occasion. I guess that, if we examine the positive market reaction to the budget where we have seen an actual lowering of interest rates already in some sectors of the financial markets, that situation certainly bears out the veracity of the Treasurer's views.

I listened with a great deal of patience to the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) and his diatribe against the government. But the simple fact of the matter is that the coalition, when it left office at the federal level, was a big taxing, big spending government. The members of the coalition do not like to hear people on this side of the House levy that charge. But it is, of course, an accurate charge borne out by the national accounts statistics.

While the honourable member for Curtin might seek to levy criticism on the government, he does not levy the same criticism at the highest taxing Liberal state government in the Commonwealth—in my state of Victoria. It is that particular government which is imposing quite enormous burdens on Victorian taxpayers by virtue of the policies that it is pursuing. The opposition hypocrisy on this matter just does not extend to the taxation area. It really extends to its whole view of the car industry and its synthetic concerns for car customers and car workers in this industry.

If we cast our minds back down the time tunnel to 1983 and we look at the profile of the car industry in Australia at that time, we can see that we had an archaic industrial structure. As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) correctly pointed out in question time, we had a precious piece of industrial archaeology in this country as far as the car industry is concerned.

For customers in that scenario, we had the car industry producing high priced cars, which meant that ordinary working people paid far more for their cars than they should have. The industry was typified by low levels of investment in new technology. We had an industrial relations system in operation and a culture in the car industry that was nothing short of disgraceful with high levels of industrial disputation and conflict in the enterprises within that sector. The export capability of the sector was simply uncompetitive and not into the export marketplace at all.

From 1983, when the coalition went out of government, to 1993, the coalition's view of the car industry changed from one of a do nothing policy to one of having a crack at car workers and decimating the industry. We do not have to go back too far to remember the famous Captain Zero and his plan to wipe out the Australian car industry in this country. That particular policy was opposed by the industry itself. It was opposed by unions in the industry. It was opposed by local governments. It was opposed by local communities, which would have been seriously affected by the coalition's policy if it had been on the treasury bench now and had been implementing the zero tariff policy.

The government's plan for the Australian car industry is a sensible, practical one that is designed to restructure the industry to meet the competitive challenges of the future. We have ushered in a new era of industrial peace to this industry. We have changed the work practices to improve productivity. We have given the industry a competitive focus and reoriented the workplace culture to achieving greater productivity. We have overseen massive investments by the major car manufacturers in the industry and it is now exporting to the rest of the world. We have strong exports of components as well.

But it is in the area of industrial relations that the hypocrisy of the opposition is most clearly exposed. Recently Ford workers struck an enterprise bargain with the Ford Motor Co. The essence of the benefits that will flow to Geelong car workers from this enterprise deal are: negotiated wage rises of between $2,500 and $4,000 per year; 13 weeks long service leave after 10 years; paid maternity leave; the introduction of family leave; increases in sick leave; the introduction of a relief operators allowance; and improved superannuation provisions. But these award improvements would be slashed by John Howard with a Kennett style individual contract system for the Ford workers at the Geelong Ford plant.
In the Geelong Advertiser of 1 June 1995, the union representatives had this to say about the deal that they struck with the Ford Motor Co:
AMWU vehicle division secretary Mr Ian Jones said the agreement was good for the future of Ford employees and consolidated the future of Ford in Australia.
AMWU vehicle division regional organiser Mr Russell Gardner said . . . "It is the best deal—it makes Ford workers the highest paid workers in the vehicle manufacturing industry in Australia,"

SPEECH.PARA: But what would the coalition do with that set of award conditions which the company and the workers have recently agreed to? It would rip the insides out of that enterprise agreement. It would strip away the award conditions and throw those workers at the mercy of a Kennett style industrial relations system that would lower their wages and take away their conditions.

PARA.TAB: I see the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) smiling away at the dispatch box at what I have just said. But he knows, as well as the workers at Ford, exactly what is in store for the Ford workers if the coalition ever achieves control of the treasury bench in this country. We would have an industrial relations system that would see Ford workers yet again in conflict with their employers on the factory floor. We would see an industrial relations system that would rip the heart out of their hard-fought wages and conditions. We would see an industrial relations system that would return this industry to the condition that it was in when we took over in 1983: a decrepit piece of archaeology that belongs somewhere in an industrial structure of the 1950s and the 1960s, not one appropriate to the competitive challenges and needs of the 1990s and beyond the year 2000.

The measures that the government has announced in this budget, including the sales tax measures, are primarily designed to give Australian households and Australian families a crack at the title. The budget is aimed at reducing the pressure on interest rates and ensuring that Australian families in the long term are able to afford homes. It is aimed an ensuring that Australian businesses are given a predictable economic environment in which to plan expansion.

Nothing that I have heard from the member for Curtin or other opposition members in this debate tonight suggests to me that the coalition has either the intellectual capacity or the administrative capability to run the Australian economy in a way that will continue to bring benefits to Australian workers. There is good reason why we do not get the opposition announcing any policies on the floor of this parliament or in any other forum throughout the length and breadth of this country. It is simply because the opposition does not have any policies at this point in time.

Those opposite give us a golden opportunity to belt them over the head while they do not have the policies and to have another crack at them when they do announce their policies. We know that when the policies are announced they will not be accepted by the Australian people and will be summarily rejected by Australian workers. We get a double crack at those opposite. We get an opportunity to belt them while they do not have the policies and then come in with the uppercut when they do announce them.

Make no mistake you people on the other side: when you do announce your tariff policies, your industrial relations policies and your taxation policies as they relate to the Australian car industry we will be watching them closely. All workers on the floor of the Ford company will know very well when they go into the polling booth on election day exactly what is in store for them if the coalition wins the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —This government stands for fairness and security for those who work and for those without work. It stands for the creation of more jobs, jobs with careers, jobs with decent pay and fair working conditions. As a community, we have to be vigilant to defend these goals and the values underlying them—the values of a cohesive, safe and caring community. That is why a little over a year ago the federal government strengthened the award system and, through it, the national minimum entitlements available to workers.

PARA.TAB: These reforms were opposed by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who was incapable of dropping his hard line on industrial relations. While generally the opposition is a policy free zone, it has not dumped the thrust of Jobsback, its 1993 wage and industrial relations policy. In 14 years the opposition leader has supported only two wage increases—two $8 safety net increases in 14 years; only $1.10 per week for every year of 14 years. That is the record of the opposition on wages and working conditions for average Australian families.

Despite the general arrogance of the opposition in refusing to stand for anything, it has not changed its industrial policy. This, too, in spite of the lessons in Victoria, where Mr Kennett has been giving Jobsback a dry run for three years now. And if Australian workers need reminding of what that means, they should just look at the Victorian government's recent actions. It is advocating a minimum wage of $8.60, which represents a cut of $60 per week or, roughly, $3,000 per year for minimum wage recipients.

The effect of the industrial relations strategies of the opposition could not be clearer to Australian workers: because it has only committed itself to minimum protection for workers, entitlements such as penalty rates, leave loading, shift allowance and family leave would be abolished under the coalition. Its spokesman, the member for Flinders, Mr Reith, is committed to abolishing the no disadvantage test. Workers receiving those entitlements would receive a real wage deduction under the coalition's industrial relations policy.

Let us consider what that would mean. For a typical unskilled labourer who currently works an average amount of overtime—which is 10 hours—without penalties, the reduction in overtime pay would be $199 per week or $4,888 per year. For a part-time worker on low pay—say, a nurse who works 16 hours each weekend—under the current arrangements his or her pay would be $299 a week but without penalties it is reduced to $184 a week. This amounts to a loss of $5,970 a year or, put another way, a 38 per cent wage reduction.

There can be only one conclusion: the Leader of the Opposition wants to rip money and conditions away from people earning average wages. The Leader of the Opposition would like nothing better than to take away from these people their annual leave loadings and their overtime.

The opposition will say that under its system you can opt to stay under the award but there will be no updating of the award over time and all new entrants to the work force will be assured of only four basic minimum conditions. The objective is to reduce real wages for ordinary workers. The net result of the policy of the Leader of the Opposition is an erosion of the working conditions and the safety net for all Australian workers. This has been demonstrated by the Kennett and other conservative state governments.

Since 1993 the size of the federal industrial relations system has increased by 400,000 workers. This has been due entirely to the neanderthal industrial policies of the conservative state governments, such as the one in Victoria. Since 1993, federally, we have seen the introduction, through the Industrial Relations Reform Act, of national minimum entitlements based on ILO conventions. These have all been opposed by the opposition. These entitlements guarantee all workers the right to a fair minimum wage, 12 months unpaid parental leave, equal pay for work of equal value and protection against unfair dismissal. All of these ILO mandated standards are in the firing line under Jobsback.

At the next federal election the danger of these attacks is greater. This time the stakes are higher. For all workers in Queensland who have escaped hardline conservative state government industrial relations policies, the Leader of the Opposition, federally, presents a new and greater threat, a threat from which there will be no escape. To all Australian workers who rely on the national minimum standards, including protection from unfair dismissal, the Leader of the Opposition will be the enemy.

What is astonishing is his belief that he can marry this kind of industrial relations policy with his pro-family rhetoric. He professes to be concerned about the battlers and yet he wants to carve away from a nurse $6,000 a year and from an unskilled person just on $5,000 a year. That is what the Leader of the Opposition is on about.

How can he be pro-family when he wants to rip away the safety net of family income earners? How can he be pro-family when he will guarantee new workers the protection of only one or two minimum entitlements? How can it be pro-family to put at risk penalty rates, shift allowances, public holidays, loadings and restrictions on working hours? How can it be pro-family to have a Victorian-style $8.60 minimum wage or to oppose the non-disadvantage test national parental leave and equal pay for work of equal value? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the adjournment I want to point out to the House the extraordinary performance we saw from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr O'Keefe) in the Main Committee. In one of the most irresponsible and misleading contributions I have ever heard, in just five minutes he made at least four grossly misleading statements. SPEECH.PARA: . . . the federal government hands to states and to local government an amount in excess of $2 billion of untied funds which is spent on roads.

But, if you look at page 3-202 of Budget Paper No. 1 at the identified road grants to the states, you will find that they were $369.2 million and that identified local road grants on page 3-205 were $358.1 million. That is a total of $727 million, not the $2 billion that the parliamentary secretary bandied around. PARA.TAB: He then talked about the amount of money that states spend on the roads as if it all came from the Commonwealth. What about all the money the motorists pay to the states in taxes? There are fuel franchise fees, registration charges, licensing fees, tolls in some cases, fines and stamp duty. All of this money is raised by the state government; it does not come from the Commonwealth. It seems he could not understand the difference and got quite confused as he continued his speech. It is a great worry to think that the parliamentary secretary for transport really does not understand this.
Let us get to the second misleading statement in his speech. He said that the Bureau of Transport Economics says that at least $6 billion a year is associated with the cost of road safety. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: What pays for that? Who pays for the ambulances, the hospitals and all of that? It comes out of untied funds that the federal government hands over.

What a load of nonsense. He obviously has not heard about compulsory third party, comprehensive insurance, private health insurance, the Medicare levy and all these things that are paid for by the motorists and none of which have got anything to do with the Commonwealth government.

PARA.TAB: To find a bit of authority he did not have to go any further than the BCA report Refocusing road reform. Page 310 of that report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Interstate Commission (ISC 1990) estimated that the `uncompensated' cost derived from subtracting . . . insurance premiums . . . from an estimated total road accident cost . . . was $1.6 billion . . .

That was just one report. Next, Dr Quiggin, someone the Labor Party likes to quote, in 1993 estimated that a `lower bound' solution of accident costs imposed by motorists on non-motorists was $1.2 billion per year—even less. Meyrick Associates in a 1994 report said:
The total external cost of accidents to be taken into account in charging policies is therefore $1350 million . . .

That is a very big difference from the $6 billion that the parliamentary secretary seemed to quote. I wonder whether he was getting himself confused. If he looked in the budget papers, he would have found that the total Commonwealth contribution to road safety was $6.4 million, not billion. Obviously this poor man is rather confused. Then he said about petrol pricing:
The petrol tax argument is a dud . . .
Even the Road Transport Forum has given it away. Even the automobile associations have given it away.
I do not know where this guy is, because he went on to say:
Show me when they last ran the petrol tax argument.
He ought to have a clear look. In the latest annual report of the Australian Automobile Association, the third paragraph of the president's report said:
Increasing the level of taxes on road users and reducing the level of expenditure on roads inevitably leads to higher transport costs, higher prices, higher inflation and less competitive exports.
Below it there is a chart showing fuel excise versus expenditure on roads. If he looked at the RTF contribution to the budget papers, he would find that in 1995 it brought the same argument up.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, this man is rather confused. In the five minutes he made at least four major misleading statements—I cannot get to the fourth one in the time available to me. Clearly, he ought to hang his head in shame. If he pretends to be a minister, then he has obviously got to do a lot better. It was a foolish contribution and I think the smirk on his face showed that even he did not take his contribution seriously. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It really is quite absurd to expect us to consider in any detail these important portfolio areas in five minutes. I intend to talk for a short time about my favourite topic, that is, tourism. I cannot do justice to that in five minutes, but I would like to make a few remarks.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, tourism remains very important to the Australian economy. I am sure many members will have read the recent report by the Tourism Forecasting Council. It is an excellent document and paints a glowing picture of Australia's tourism industry, not only of the consistent growth that has occurred over the last 15 years but also, more importantly, of the very healthy looking forecasts for the industry between now and the year 2000. It says that in the year 2000 6.3 million people are expected to visit Australia, that is more than double the number that visited in 1993, and for the next 10 years inbound tourism is expected to grow by 10 per cent a year.

Tourism is well known for its contribution to export earnings of around $10.6 billion per annum. It is a very important industry to Australia. I suspect that the government has done very little to assist the tourism industry. The tourism industry is one of those Australian industries which has grown despite the government. It is a great tribute to the many small business people in every part of the tourism industry who have made the industry what it is. Many of those people are my constituents, so I see at first hand exactly what they are doing on a day-to-day basis.

There are lots of reasons why we should not be complacent about our tourism industry. When the vice-president of All Nippon Airways visited Australia last week, he made some very pertinent remarks. He informed us—it was news to a lot of people—that Japanese tourists find visiting Australia expensive compared with going to the west coast of the United States.

Honourable members might think, with the way the $A has depreciated against the yen in recent times, that we would find it very expensive to go to Japan, but the point is that we are almost paying the Japanese to come here. If Australia is an expensive destination for the Japanese, of all people, then it probably ought to ring warning bells for the government to ask why. I hope that the comments made by that visiting Japanese airline executive will be taken very seriously and that we might look at that. I suspect the fact that we have an archaic industrial relations system is probably a major factor in contributing to that lack of competitiveness. We need to be very careful. As was pointed out, the industry is volatile for all sorts of reasons and we should not be complacent about the fact that the Japanese will continue to support Australia to the extent that they do.

It was interesting that the vice-president of All Nippon Airways also talked about the need for Australia to revise its visa system. That is something the government ought to consider. I know it comes up from time to time and perhaps, with VJ day approaching, it may not be entirely appropriate to put it firmly on the agenda at this particular time. Our visa system is, once again, becoming out of date and out of step with a lot of other countries. Few Asians are overstayers and the Japanese do not overstay in any great number.

There is evidence that when other countries have revised their visa system it has led to an increase in tourism. So Australia ought to make it as attractive as possible for Asians to come here. Certainly, we ought to continue to encourage Japanese visitors to come here. Revising the visa restrictions which currently apply would be one way of doing that.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration recently brought down its report Taxing relaxing. There are lots of recommendations in the report which I hope the government will look at. None of the recommendations surfaced in the budget, but I am prepared to concede that that was because the report came down shortly before the budget. Our visiting Japanese airline executive called for incentives to be put in place. As a result of that call, it becomes clear that incentives are needed. EMDG is one, but there are numerous others recommended here. Rather than incentives for the tourism industry, what we have in the budget are a number of disincentives, that is, an increase in company tax, increases in tax on building materials, an increase in sales tax on motor cars and all sorts of things which are going to make it more expensive for tourism operators.

There is a shortage of accommodation, not only on the Gold Coast but in Cairns. We need to do everything we can to fix that problem as quickly as possible, but what the government has done in this budget is actually to make the problem worse. I believe that is something that needs to be looked at urgently. The other imposts on small business that came in the budget do impact directly on our tourism industry, and I can assure the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that those—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) focused on tourism. It is worth noting that, when compared with 1983, tourism in 1995 is a massive contributor to the Australian national economy. Whereas it was not even an industry that was fully recognised by the federal government in 1983, when the Liberals were last in power, today tourism represents an $11.2 billion earner to Australia in terms of foreign exchange.

PARA.TAB: There has been a massive increase in the number of tourists who come here, and the growth is continuing. They are coming not only from Japan but from the whole north Asia region. From Korea, from Taiwan and even from China, the number of visitors coming here has been growing at seven, eight and 10 per cent over the last couple of years; and that is because we have had a concerted strategy of marketing into Japan and into north Asia as well.

With the appropriations that are allocated in this year's budget, the Australian Tourism Commission will be able to continue with that job. It is developing the increasing sophistication demanded by the market. People packaging holidays in Japan tell us that these days the Japanese tourist is looking for more than the tightly targeted package that would have been sold and was accepted in their tours in the past. Now, tourists from Japan are looking for a broader range of experiences. They are wanting to get outside the Cairns area. They are wanting to get to the outback areas. There are a lot more rural holidays taken by Asian tourists, as well as by other tourists coming to Australia. The whole strategy that the Tourism Commission has been adopting has been focused on trying to broaden out the tourism product that visitors coming to Australia can enjoy.

A couple of weeks ago we had the launch of the regional tourism program. Again, that was an initiative of the government which we made a commitment about before the last election and which is being implemented. It is ensuring a building of tourism infrastructure all across Australia. It does not matter whether we go to Queensland or to places like Strahan, on the west coast of Tasmania: the Commonwealth government is there, helping to build the infrastructure that is needed to provide the tourism potential of that region.

I note we have a number of members here from Queensland. The fact of the matter is that the programs we launched in the regional tourism strategy and in the ecotourism strategy were all about trying to broaden the capacity of the infrastructure that exists throughout the whole of the state of Queensland—much of it in the regional and provincial parts of Queensland—to make the tourism product in those areas more accessible. We know from the research that the Tourism Commission has done in Japan that that is striking a very positive chord with the Japanese tourists that want to come to Australia.

Mention was made of industrial relations, and the impediment that that might or might not be to the tourism industry. I note that before the budget the big cry of the opposition was that there was going to be a bed tax. That was the big scare that was being run prior to the budget. Of course, that did not eventuate. That was another thing the opposition had on the wish list of things it hoped might be in the budget, but it was not. By its continuing commitment to the Tourism Commission and to the Department of Tourism in the budget allocations, the government has showed that it is maintaining very strongly the Tourism Commission's drive in its international marketing strategy.

When it comes to industrial relations, the member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), who has a very close interest in tourism because of the nature of the tourism product that exists in the Townsville area, reminded me of what the Liberals were actually proposing before the last election with their $3 per hour youth wage. That would have gone very much to the living standards of young people working in the tourism industry in Queensland. We rejected that, and the people of Australia rejected that.

We are committed to ensuring that the growth of our tourism industry, which has been growing at seven and eight per cent each year for several years, is maintained. We are committed to ensuring that we take advantage of the big opportunities that are going to come on line over the next few years in marketing Australia's profile around the world, with things like the Olympics and other major events, and that we get full value in the region. The Indonesian tourism minister was here a few weeks ago, and others have come. We know from the range of international visitors who have come here how much potential they see in terms of development of the bilateral relationships in tourism. These appropriations make absolutely crystal clear that we are going to ensure that the Commonwealth plays its rightful role in achieving the full aspirations that we all have for the tourism industry in Australia.
Proposed expenditures agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had the opportunity of speaking here before, but I think it is deplorable that the government has cut off the discussion on the budget, that the debate has been transferred over here on limited time, and that we now have to discuss the estimates of Department of Industry, Science and Technology, and other departments, on a five-minute basis.

It wishes to hurry to the election and to get rid of the budget—it does not matter what is in it. The hallmark of this government is that the people of Australia must not be told too much.

The government took the soft option: it is an election year, therefore up with taxation. Consequently, investment will fall, growth will fall, and a fall in employment will follow. I listen to the hot air that comes from the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook). I quote this little effort, in reference to taking a delegation to the Far East:

PARA.TAB: In the few remaining moments I have, I want to make some comments in relation to the performance of a couple of the programs administered by the department. For example, Australia's manufacturing sector has recorded growth over the last two to three years in a way which has been unmatched in our history. It has been responsible for nearly a quarter of the total growth of the Australian economy since early 1991, even though it only accounts for 16 per cent of the total economy. Production in the manufacturing sector rose by 9.3 per cent in real terms in 1993-94, compared to overall economic growth of 4.2 per cent. It is an outstanding achievement.

The growth in exports of our elaborately transformed manufactures—ETMs—has been particularly impressive over the last decade. Australia exported $2.4 billion of ETMs in 1984. In 1994, this figure was $11.5 billion. That is a growth of 16 per cent a year over the decade. Again, a truly outstanding milestone achievement. So the growth in manufacturing and export service industries demonstrates the success of these policies. The appropriations for the industry, science and technology portfolio are $2.8 billion, approximately the same as in 1994-95. In my speech on the appropriation bills, I covered a number of agencies and programs being administered by the portfolio this year and I will not add to those remarks today. But the government has set out in the budget a new phase of our support for one particular program which I want to make a few remarks on, and that is the textile, clothing and footwear industries program. This new TCF development package will continue the process of restructuring, it will help raise productivity to meet the industry's goal of $2 billion of exports by the year 2000. And, importantly, the package will assist the industries to meet the challenges and take advantage of the opportunities that will emerge from Australia's integration within APEC.

The department also administers the investment promotion and facilitation program. This is designed to inform overseas investors of Australia's strengths as an investment location. The budget funding of $9 million will continue the program for another year while an evaluation is carried out. I am very proud of this particular program. It also includes activities such as the regional headquarters campaign and the funding of feasibility studies for eligible major investment projects. The work on the investment promotion has encouraged a number of companies to establish regional headquarters in Australia. Among them are British Telecom, CAE Electronics and Methode Electronics, to name a few.

Also in the budget $3.75 million has been allocated over three years to continue the reform process in the construction industry. That will enable the establishment of an Australian construction industry council which will then be able to implement the second stage of the micro-economic reform agenda, with the council drawing its members from leading industry firms. The government will also undertake an independent safety assessment of the Lucas Heights nuclear reactor at a cost of $2 million, and that assessment will be carried out by independent researchers in accordance with International Atomic Energy Agency guidelines. This is an important initiative in the methodology we adopt in developing the overall future of the Lucas Heights nuclear reactor.

Australian participation in international relationships is an important element of the science and technology program. This year, activities will include the implementation of new arrangements for science and technology cooperation with Indonesia, and the signing of a new science and technology agreement with Korea, to name a couple.

The innovation statement will be brought down by the minister later this year. That is designed to encourage an innovation culture in Australia. Generally, the portfolio is making an important contribution to the development of that statement and its culture by consultation right throughout the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1995-96, under the Foreign Affairs and Trade allocation, I wish to firstly speak about one specific commitment, which is to reopen the Australian embassy in Beirut, Lebanon, which is a specialised item in this year's budget referred to in the budget papers. I believe it is only fair, proper and reasonable that Australia re-establish its embassy level links in Beirut, Lebanon to reflect the peace process in the Middle East but also to reflect the real progress that Lebanon is making against very difficult odds in circumstances which are extraordinarily difficult relating to its neighbours, most notably both Israel and Syria.

Despite that, there is a spirit alive and well in Lebanon to get on with the job of rebuilding Beirut and rebuilding Lebanon. I salute that spirit and hope that the embassy, on its reopening in the same building as it was in before its closure in the middle of the civil year, will reward Australian promotional effort not only on the diplomatic front but also in helping to boost our trade to the Middle East and our trade to Lebanon, where we have a small live sheep trade and other items.

The second point I want to make is that the whole focus and effort of the trade component of Foreign Affairs and Trade must be mindful of the fact that Australia is losing market share in certain key growing Asian markets. It is not quite good enough to say that, as the Asian economies move on and further mature and develop from their very small economic bases, they are going to show huge growth figures; their needs are going to be different, and that explains justifiably, in the eyes of some, why it is okay for Australia to lose market share in some of these key Asian economic tigers.

I would argue that there can be absolutely no complacency about our trading and export efforts to Asia and elsewhere. We hear the government referring to it repeatedly. I make the point that, when one analyses the figures on any objective and properly comparative criteria—as I, particularly in a paper in January this year, have said; and as, more recently, the shadow minister for foreign affairs has said—one can have no doubt that we are losing our market share, and that is a matter of legitimate concern. In the context of the allocation of these appropriations for Foreign Affairs and Trade, I want to see attention brought to bear on that circumstance, on the need to further diversify our export efforts, and on the need to, in fact, lift our game against some pretty nasty competition coming from around the Pacific and elsewhere in the world.

The last point I want to make in the time available is to refer to the foreign aid component in the budget, which has again fallen as a percentage of GDP and, of course, falls well short of the allocation of the policy objective laid down at the national ALP conferences in Hobart. There is a need to be very careful about Australian taxpayer dollars being used on aid. There is, of course, a case for foreign aid: it does indeed help Australia and does help many people in the world who are disadvantaged, and I am, in general terms, supportive of the foreign aid program.

The targeting, efficiency and effectiveness of that aid program is something for legitimate scrutiny by this parliament and, indeed, by the minister for overseas aid, most notably in his comments with regard to one particular international organisation. I highlight the fact that, as a percentage of GDP, aid has fallen well short of the government's own foreign aid objectives. We must work harder to drive those foreign aid dollars just as far as they can be driven to produce the maximum effective outcome.

So far as asset sales generally are concerned, as they affect Defence, there have been a number of assets that have been identified for disposal; but it has not been the top of the market, as it were, to sell many of those assets. Defence is keen to ensure that it does get a good return on those assets, and I would anticipate that given the change in the broad economic climate we will see some of those assets to which the member for Groom referred being able to be put on the market and realised during the course of the current financial year. I am not in the position to provide him with specific advice on ASTA and the AIDC, but I would be quite happy to look into that for him.

In relation to the Nomad aircraft, another issue which I know he has pursued for some time, there is an ongoing investigation. I understand that the findings from that inquiry are due to be presented to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) by the end of June this year. In fact, at a recent function I was talking to one of the officers involved in that review, and was advised that it is still ongoing. I know they have not completed their work at this time. Hopefully that work will be completed in time for a report to be made available to the minister by the end of June, and we will then all be in a position to make some clear assessment about what future role, if any, the Nomad has in the Australian Defence Force.

TALK.START.PARA: —If any.

—Indeed. I will finally turn to the big picture question of the amount of money defence globally gets out of the budget. As the member for Groom correctly points out, it is a smidgin under $10 billion. That does represent an increase, as a percentage of government outlays. It also represents about two per cent of GDP.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that the percentage of GDP is often used as a yardstick. I have made it very plain, for some time, that I have never regarded percentage of GDP as a dramatically useful measure for defence effectiveness. It may have some use when you are trying to compare across national boundaries. But even there it is very limited, because it is a percentage of a fluctuating figure, and that does not produce too much in terms of actual hardware or personnel on the ground.

I will just illustrate that. I have just come from a lunch with visiting members of the Japanese parliament. The gentlemen sitting beside me were talking about defence matters. Bear in mind that Japan has what is the third largest defence force in the world—it is, arguably, the second largest, if you take account of what has happened in the Soviet Union. The gentleman sitting beside me said, `How much do you spend on defence? What percentage of GDP?' I said, `Two per cent.' He said, `Oh, that is twice as much as we spend.' There is the answer.

It is two per cent. It also happens to be maintaining defence commitments in all but real terms. There has been only a very slight reduction in defence outlays in the last year. I should not let the opportunity pass without noting that, on the last occasion, the opposition did have a formal policy on defence. At the last election, the opposition undertook to reduce outlays on defence by $200 million beyond the cuts which we were programming. The two per cent figure is not one I would rest on.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the average time taken by his Department to process an account for nursing services between receipt and payment.
(2) Does his Department issue individual cheques to service providers for each patient receiving care.
(3) Is his Department able to issue a single cheque on a regular basis to a service provider for a number of patients; if not, why not.
(4) Will his Department implement the procedure referred to in part (3) to assist service providers to reduce the costs of bank fees and paperwork.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) My Department undertakes to pay all claims within 28 days of receipt. The current average across Australia for the processing of nursing service claims is 14.2 days.

(2) My Department issues cheques to providers three times a week (for example, Monday, Wednesday, Friday). All cheques processed for a provider are included in the next cheque run, for example, claims processed for a provider on Tuesday would be included in the Wednesday run.

If only one claim for one patient is processed for that provider in this time, a cheque for only one patient will be sent. If more claims are processed for that provider in this time, the cheque will cover all the claims processed and will normally be for multiple patients. Up to 50 service vouchers may be attached to each claim form.

If a provider is a member of a pay group, the cheque issued will be made out to the one person/company and it will be that person/company's responsibility to issue cheques to each of the pay group members. It may be that the company issues individual cheques to each of the group members.

A service provider (such as a community nurse) may also nominate a payee provider (for example, a nursing agency) to receive payment for the services provided. In this case the cheque is sent to the payee provider, who would then pay the service provider.
(3) My Department is already able to issue single cheques to a provider covering a number of patients.
(4) The procedure suggested is already in place.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Poultry: Export to People's Republic of China

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 6 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is there a ban on the export of all Australian poultry and poultry products to the People's Republic of China; if so, (a) how long is the ban expected to apply, (b) is the ban attributable to an outbreak of avian influenza in Queensland (c) is the influenza outbreak confined to Queensland; if so, why does the ban apply to all Australian poultry and poultry products and (d) what action will the Government take to (i) control and confine the outbreak of avian influenza in Queensland and (ii) protect Australian poultry exporters, including two in the electoral division of Stirling, and their employees, who depend on the Chinese market.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The People's Republic of China issued a notice effective 19 January 1995 banning the imports of all poultry meat/products from Australia in accordance with the China quarantine law.

After representations by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) the Chinese authorities advised on 1 March 1995 that cooked poultry meat products from the States and Territories other than Queensland will be permitted into the People's Republic of China. The import permit will be issued by the Administration of Animal and Plant Quarantine upon receiving permit application from the importer.

Each consignment of permitted above-mentioned products must be accompanied by a Veterinary Health Certificate issued by AQIS attesting that the products have been subjected to a specified heat treatment.
(a) the Chinese authorities have advised, if there is no further case of fowl plague on 23 June 1995 according to the International Animal Health Code then the Chinese Authority may lift the ban.
(b) the ban is attributable to the avian influenza outbreak in Queensland.
(c) the avian influenza outbreak in December 1994 was confined to Queensland.

The ban is applied in accordance with the Law of the People's Republic of China on Entry and Exit Animal and Plant Quarantine and the Office Internationale Des Epizooties (OIE) International Animal Health Code.

(d)(i) the Commonwealth and other State and Territory Governments have provided financial assistance to the Queensland Government, which has constitutional responsibilities for animal disease control, under the Commonwealth/States cost sharing agreement for certain exotic animal diseases, which includes Avian influenza in it virulent form. Assistance has also been provided with diagnosis and advice by the CSIRO Australian Animal Health Laboratory and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

The Queensland Department of Primary Industries declared a restricted area around the affected property, destroyed all poultry on the farm and undertook extensive disease surveillance of other properties in the vicinity of the affected property. It is now believed that the outbreak of avian influenza in Queensland has been eradicated.

(ii) the Government has made representations, both by AQIS directly and by the Australian Embassy in Beijing, to firstly limit the ban to the infected area immediately surrounding the infected property, or alternatively, to limit the ban to the poultry products from Queensland only.
These representations have been particularly useful in that cooked product from all of Australia, except Queensland is now permitted.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 30 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) broadcast netball matches played between Australia and South Africa during 1995; if so,
(a) how many matches, on what dates and at what times,

(b) did the ABC receive payments or other consideration for broadcasting the matches; if so, (i) who made them, (ii) in what form were they made, (iii) when were they made, (iv) what agreement, arrangement or understanding was entered into and (v) did the ABC assess the agreement against its guidelines before (A) entering into the agreement or (B) broadcasting the events,
(c) if the ABC received no payments or other considerations, what are the details of each agreement, arrangement or understanding entered into relating to the broadcasting of the matches, and
(d) did the ABC seek the right to (i) regulate the display of commercial advertising material placed around the match venues or (ii) modify its placement to alter the amount visible during broadcast.

(2) When it agrees to broadcast sporting events, does the ABC retain the right to refuse to broadcast an event or part of an event or modify the broadcast if commercial advertising material is displayed at the venue; if so, what are the details of the sports, events, organising bodies, advertisers and amounts of advertising material concerned.

(3) Will the Government impose restrictions on the ABC or its agents and contracting parties concerning the receipt of payment or other consideration for broadcasting events containing commercial advertising material; if so, what restrictions.
(4) Will the Government ensure that the ABC remains free of commercial or other pressure related to advertising material displayed at sporting events broadcast by the ABC; if so, by what means.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes
(a) Three. On 18 February 1995 at 7.30pm, on 22 February 1995 at 8.3Opm and on 25 February 1995 at 7.30pm.

(b) No. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 at s.25(3) provides that the Corporation does not have power to accept any payment or other consideration for the broadcasting of any announcement, program or other matter. However, the ABC did enter into a co-production agreement (see (c) below), as allowed under s.25(5) of the Act.

(c) The only agreement entered into by the ABC in connection with these Netball Tests was with the All Australian Netball Association (AANA). Under that agreement the ABC acquired the right to make a recording of each of the Tests and the right to exercise the following broadcasting rights in respect of those recordings:
Australian free-to-air television rights
South African free-to-air and pay television rights
Non-exclusive Australia Television rights
Co-production funds with AANA partly offset the costs of making the recordings and in return they received the following rights:
All other free-to-air and pay television rights worldwide
Worldwide video and non-theatric rights.

(d) The agreement requires AANA at the ABC's request to remove or reposition promotional signage or other matter present at the venue in order that the ABC may ensure that its telecast of the events does not result in any contravention of its obligations under the Act and complies with its Editorial Policies. The Policies state in relation to signage

"Organisers of events which the ABC wishes to broadcast should be informed by the prohibition of advertising on the domestic radio and television services and Radio Australia, and ABC cameras must not dwell upon on-site advertising. Incidental coverage of signage which mentions commercial products would not, in law, constitute advertising. If an Executive Producer considers that coverage of an event cannot avoid dwelling on particular commercial names and the organiser refuses to relocate signs, the matter should be referred immediately to the relevant Department Head for appropriate action."

(2) The agreement provision referred to in (d) above is a standard inclusion in sporting event agreements of this nature, as is a further provision that the ABC shall not be liable in damages or otherwise should the ABC decide not to telecast an event for any reason whatsoever ie, there is no obligation to broadcast.

(3) As noted in 1(b), the ABC Act includes restrictions on the ABC accepting payment or other consideration for broadcasting events. Section 31(1) of the Act provides that the Corporation shall not broadcast advertisements. It is a duty of the ABC Board (s.8(1)(b) of the Act) to maintain the independence and integrity of the Corporation.
(4) See (3) above.
